reviewText:
30+ hours in
Initially, I liked Year One, but I cannot recommend it now that I've seen the bugs and how little content there was.

tl;dr - almost every old bug still exists in the game. I paid good money to improve the game experience and all I got was this reskin (and some NEW bugs!).

The base game
I enjoyed the base game with the upgraded visuals. There were also some mechanical tweaks (mainly the vehicles now handle according to Earth gravity) and lovely additions to the soundtrack; it wasn't a new experience, but an improved one. The Freaks got balanced, you didn't get as overwhelmed with tasks, the CLEO drops and reskins brought a little spice into things - it was quite nice revisiting the game I love, warts and all.

The new content ran out a bit too quickly, however, and the endgame was boring with the last stretch of missions and looting a little flat as usual, but I felt it was okay value for 24 hours of gameplay. After all, I was getting 2 refreshed DLCs too, right?

Dealbreaker DLC
But then there's Lifeline. My first three playthroughs had major game-breaking bugs, and the whole 'refreshed' DLC is riddled with old bugs that have been reported to UD Labs time and again. NOTHING has been fixed, and there is very little additional content for Lifeline - the reskins are lame and there are no new weapons (the CLEO ones suck compared to army stuff).

I felt utterly cheated, still do after 8+ hours of gameplay.

When Fighting 7/Bladed 7 Kung-Fu Vince falls through a bridge after exiting your vehicle and gets killed by a solo Feral under said bridge, you know your game is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed. Never mind the CLEO missions that don't spawn, zombies that spawn inside the ground, disappearing items, worthless AI, Journal glitching out, wrong voice clips playing for your player character etc.

This really put the base game into perspective for me, too. In the end, the improvements were marginal at best and left a lot to be desired.

The bottom line
This remake is way overpriced for what it is - reskins and some extra tunes. The mechanical tuning should have been done for the original, it was borderline bugfixing! I paid good money thinking I would get actual content and bugfixes/polish too, but NOPE. I still love the base game for what it is (it's complicated with Lifeline...), but if you're an old player, don't buy this for the full price, about 70% off would be fair.

If you still want to play the same old game and can stand the bugs, that is.

New players? Buyer beware. The base game is still one of the better zombie survival games and has unique mechanics that are quite enjoyable, but the devs don't seem to be interested in fixing and expanding the game - and that is a bad, bad sign.

reviewText:
I'll start by saying I loved the original State of Decay and the two DLC's, I loved them to death so much I bought them twice.  Once for the Xbox 360 and once for the PC.  Now I can say I purchased them a third time, because this one is esstentially the same as the original and the DLC.

When I started to hear news of a newer updated version of the game my heart skipped a beat.  Maybe we'd finally get a version of the game that wasn't handicapped by the outdated consoles they were created for.   Did I get that.. well the answer is a yes, and a no.  While the game looks far better than the previous version, it just isn't worth recommending for a full price purchase if you already own the original game.

If you don't own the original already, this is a good deal, you get the base game and all the DLC and the patches and bug fixes which were never brought to the original game.  Excuses are just that excuses, saying the patches and bugs weren't possible to fix because the game was restricted by the console release... WHY?  This isn't a console, it's the PC.  Those excuses don't work on this format..

Bottom line remains, if you own State of Decay.. save your money, if you don't own the game, the YOSE is the way to go.  Great value for your money, but this HD upgrade was totally  unnecessary and the bugs/glitches should have been fixed in the previous version.
voteText: 677 of 793 people (85%) found this review helpful 14 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Make a note
First of all, if you already own the original game and every available DLC then don't bother buying this unless you are looking for slightly better graphics, a few new weapons and vehicle skins and bug fixes (and new bugs). The game is still pretty much the same experience.

And here we go
If you are  new  to this game and interested, then I'd most likely recommend buying it. Don't mind the negative reviews on this edition of the game. Instead read the ones on the original one (which is no longer available for purchase at the moment) since they tell more about the experience than these on YOSE. Why? Because most of these tell about how this edition was released only to make money out of small updates and about the bugs that make the game worse. The worst thing is that the original game is not receiving any of the new content and updates that are included in this edition. I can understand the pain and I agree that it's a horrible move, but I'd like to direct this short review specifically towards everyone who has no experience with the original game.

I'll let you know about the game's basics and the good and the bad in short.

State of Decay
The base game
Survival in zombie apocalypse
3rd person view
Melee weapons and guns
Cars
Collecting loot (from food and medicine to weapons and building materials)
Base management
Expanding your community
Helping your neighbors with problems
Doing missions that eventually lead to the end of the game
YOSE Day One Edition
2x DLCs: Breakdown and Lifeline
Improved graphics
An exclusive character
Two new guns
A new car and already existing vehicles with custom skins
New missions (looting supply crates)
The Good and The Bad
Pros
+Looting and managing inventory is easy
+Combat is alright
+Base management is simple and clear
+Vehicles are easy to control (most of the time)
+Moving alone can actually be really dangerous (it's good to have someone with you)
+Graphics are nice...

Cons
-...but they can get a bit ugly (for ex. in the woods)
-Fighting with melee weapons gets repetitive
-Missions also get repetitive
-Simplicity is a minor impact
-Voice acting is propably the most repetitive thing in the game and needs a bigger variety
(same sentences are repeated alot)
-Vehicles feel a bit too fragile sometimes
-The game is still screaming for co-op
-Minor bugs that are close to breaking missions
-Performance needs tweaking (fps drops)

Nutshell
Gameplay: 7.5/10
Graphics: 8/10
Sounds: 7.5/10 (Including voice acting)
Performance: 7/10
Story: 6/10

Conclusion
State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition was made only with money in mind and so it should propably be avoided by veterans unless you need this new content and bug fixes + the upcoming fixes for the new and old bugs. In the other hand, this is something that fans of survival games should look into. You can spend alot of time while playing this game. Even I spent over 12 hours on the base game and tried out one of the DLCs (Lifeline) that I have not played before (I did play the original game and the Breakdown DLC back in the day). The other DLC (Breakdown) will leave you with even more hours on your counter. The game is propably best played with a controller.

Newcomers
8/10
Veterans
5-6/10
The polished yet dirty version/edition of a fun game"


Please let me know if I missed anything. You are also free to give me your own opinions! :)

Thank you"

reviewText:
Don't buy it. Nothing is remastered here, its all a lie.
There is only 3 little changes in the game that arent worth it if you alredy own the first one.
They increased shadow resolution, added few more particles in some areas and adjusted contrast and bright for better view. All of which could have been done with a simple update. In fact, some of those settings can be changed with ENB series.
If you never bough the original game, go for it, it still a good game.
If you already have it, nothing new to see here, dont waste your money.

And for the devs, I would feel really ashamed of selling the same game to the users that helped you to grow and gain popularity buying your product. I dont think that your userbase deserves such bad behavior and scam from you all.
Too bad I couldnt play the game till few days ago even tho I had preordered it, otherwise I would surely asked for the Steam refund without doubt.

reviewText:
This edition is the second paid version the developer put on steam. While it pretty annoying by itself for having to pay for what is essentially a (performance?) update, it is rather unforgivable that this game still, in its present state, is extremely buggy; character floating in the air, running through solid walls, teleporting, etc. The sheer amount of this types of bugs I encountered is mind boggling. Arguable, there is a graphical update in this version, which makes everything a lot brighter, which in my opinion does not help the game. Let's not talk about game design, while it could have been a lot better, at least it does not totally ruin the game like the bugs do. With the exception of course, by the fact that your companions tend to run away or leave you while heading out. This is especially no fun when you try to clear out an infestation, raising the chances considerably to be overrun and die. The more so because you often don't notice that you're  left to your own!

I would avoid this game, whether you played the original version or not.

In comparison, I give Darksiders II Deathinitive Edition a thumbs up.

reviewText:
As of writing this only about 2 weeks after release I will have to sadly not recommend this game, at least not if you already own the original. If you don't then yes i highly recommend it, State of Decay is an amazing game that came out of nowhere and pulls you into a really cool survival type game, has an ok story nothing too amazing and it does have bugs but you will find yourself not being able to put it down. Now as for this re-release no it is not worth it in the slightest, I bought it of course clamoring to replay this game because it is that enjoyable, to find that they simply put flames on some trucks added some loot crates and added vehicle storage into the base game. Other than that nothing is different, no noticeable bug fixes, things are still wonky here and there, which believe is fine, but in a re-release that wants you to rebuy the game at basically what was almost full price I expect polish and upgrades which are not present here.

If you are a returning fan, don't spend the money unless you truly just want to regain achievements and replay
If you are new to the series I highly recommend this, (mainly because it's just State of Decay with a different name)
9/10 for State of Decay     5/10 for this Remaster""

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game because it is so ridiculously glitchy.  Being new to the game, I read the reviews, and despite the negative recommendations because this edition should have been a patch instead of a remastered version, I got it anyways.  The indications of poor graphics performance and poor physics were fairly slight in the reviews, while predominant complaints were the former, so I thought, how bad could it be?  Let me tell you new comers, it's that bad.  Let  me break down the problems this game faces.

-sluggish controls;  The action you try to perform may or may not be done on the first button press.  This leads to over zealous and useless button mashing.
-Zombies literally spawn right in front of you and are attacking you before they are visibly spawned in.  This is most notable when the game decides to mess you up, you'll see a few zombies, go whale on them, the music will kick into more serious tones, then you are swarmed with zombies that were nowhere around 2 seconds ago.  You'll start seeing them spawn in right behind a zombie you are executing.
-team npcs are obviously programmed to be more of a nuciance than a help. They are notorious about standing in doorways, not attacking enemies until the last second.  They will NOT help you carry stuff, such as supplies you find, which really makes them pretty useless.  You cannot direct them to move, attack or anything otherwise useful.
-The camera is not your friend.  Half the battle is keeping up with the camera.  Especially while driving.  Nothing says pain in the @$$ like driving with the WASD scheme and rotating the camera manually.  90% of all car accidents in this game is due to blind spots from the camera nemesis.  When fighting, sometimes all you can see is the back side of a zombie or your head.
-Aiming can be a real pain in the nether region.  Scoped weapons aren't truely scoped, as you only zoom in ever so slightly, but the sight is still over the shoulder, and it leads to frustratingly difficult long shots.  Against all survival guide recommendations, spray and pray will end up being the order of the day when you inevitably get swarmed, hopefully you brought enough snacks, painkillers and a backup melee weapon because it's gonna turn into melee when you run out of ammo.
-Vehicle physics seem to have been written by a toddler, because the physics are either as stiff as a board or as bouncy as a rubber ball.  Run over a zombie, you may dent your hood, or you may take your vehicle for a tour of the solar system, you're at the whim of random physics.  On that note, if walking everywhere wasn't a sure recipe for disaster because of materializing zombies, it would be easier to walk.
-Walls and doors may or may not stop a zombie attack or the flames from a molotov.
-Street curb can be an invisible barrier.  Make sure you take a running leap to get up on that sidewalk.
-To search containers, you have to position yourself perfectly in front of it, you can't open that cooler lid standing beside it, because that's IMPOSSIBLE, the same goes for entering and exiting vehicles as well as putting items in the storage compartment.
-Climbing down a ladder can be a perilous endeavor.  Sometimes you'll climb down normally, othertimes you'll swan dive off the platform.  Oh, did I mention how the useless NPCs like to stand in front of doors?  Yeah, they do that with ladders too.  Feel free to push them off, not that you'll teach them any kind of lesson but you'll feel better...
-Last but not least;  the missions are so repetitive, and absolutely pointless...  <insert name> is in a tough spot." blah blah blah...  The idle NPCs constantly go out

reviewText:
One of the saddest stories in video game development.

TL;DR - While there is a great game buried under here, it's buried beneath an entirely unplayable mess. Don't buy this game until the devs make it very public that they've fixed it, should they ever actually do that. Until then, try and find a way to get the original.

*

I loved this game when it came out. I remember watching the trailers and having my hopes raised so high at the prospect of an open world zombie survival game of this calibre. And when it came out, it actually lived up to the hype. Somewhere in the outdated graphics, the lack of co-op, the awful sound design, and the disjointed voice acting, was a fantastic game with amazing mechanics. Hours were spent glued to my xbox fighting off waves of zombies, scrounging for supplies, searching every container looking for new weapons (and there must be hundreds of different weapons), building up bases, rescuing survivors and expanding my group.

And then Breakdown came out, and I was ecstatic. It's like they realized their weaknesses and limitations, and decided to devote their attention to building their strengths. While the story of State of Decay was decent enough to push you around the map and through events in the game, they now gave us the world as our playground and challeneged us to survive for as long as possible in whatever way we chose. Once again, many hours were lost.

And then came Lifeline, and in my opinion, the cracks started to show. It was still every bit as fun as the original, but what I'd hoped would be an entire urban centre to explore, turned out to be almost entirely inaccessible. The map consists of a large city area of which the entirety is inaccessible. The only areas you can explore are the suburban-esque areas of the outer limits of the city, which contain little more than the same houses and buildings you saw in the original. But despite all that, the fun was still there. The story was interesting enough, and being given a pile of new, military grade weapons to mow down zombies with was a blast. So even though the fun was shorter lived than the original, it still held up to its own.

And then...this. This terrible, awful, wretched money grab they shamelessly put out. The base game is still there somewhere, but it has been completely buried in a buggy, laggy, entirely unplayable experience. They boast about being remastered in 1080p, as well as improved textures and animations, but the game looks almost no different than the original. The menus are a little sharper, the icons look a little crisper, but the player models, zombies, vehicles, the world itself is unnoticeably different. The only thing that's really changed is that the game can't keep up with itself anymore. Frame skips are constant, even in low texture density areas. Bugs are rampant, with your characters floating in the air or falling through the world, zombies pop in and out of existence all around you, the game crashes to desktop.

And just to add insult to injury, the devs are charging more than the base game for this, and have made the original, playable version unpurchaseable. Coming up on a year after its release, the devs have seemingly made no moves to acknowlege that their product is broken, nevermind actually fix this game and make it playable again. One can only hope that day is coming.

reviewText:
Update 1 on November 19, 2015:
Almost 7 months after release, UL has finally released a big content patch. Out of curiosity, I will be reinstalling to see if it addresses some of the bugs I mentioned.

Update 2 on November 27, 2015:
Everything seems to work fine now. Only took them 7 months to actually patch the damn thing.

I really want to recommend this game, but I can't in good conscience tell people to go out and get YOSE given the state it's in. On paper, it sounds great: HD re-release of 2013's State of Decay, all DLC included, bonus missions and new characters for the Breakdown DLC. I got the original State of Decay around the time it came out of Early Access back in late 2013 and it was plagued by bugs that eventually got patched out. So, imagine my surprise when playing the re-release only to discover they brought back the same bugs. To list a few:

- Opening up the journal will running or driving will lock your character in that direction infinitely until you press the same direction key again.
- Incorrect character voices. A female character will use her own voice to say one line, then switch to another female voice, and then cheer in a deep male voice.
- Issues with map geometry, i.e. with a horde right on your butt, you'll sprint across the street only to hit what the game thinks is an invisible wall because the curb is like half a foot above the street.
- Wonky car physics, meaning that driving over what you think is a small rock will rocket your vehicle into the stratosphere and kill your character.
- Worst of all, the infinite loading screen glitch is back. Anyone who played the original SoD at launch will remember this, where if you switch between characters, the game will load in as the new character, but the loading screen will float in place forever. It's easily fixed by exiting to the menu and loading back in, but this shouldn't be an issue in the first place.

It's almost been a month since launch with no patch (other than one to fix the import save function). Until YOSE gets fixed or falls to a price you think is reasonable, I say skip it. If you've not played the original, you can get that and all the DLC for less than $10 or $15 during a sale.

reviewText:
Decided to make this more coherent aswell as more thorough.

Pros:
-Same good gameplay from the previous, aborted child, with solid combat.
-Good, though run of the mill 'special zombies' (Freaks), the Screamer (Killing Floor Siren though this one disables character while screaming), the Bloater (basically a Left 4 Dead Smoker/Killing Floor Bloatbile hybrid since it doesn't tongue but it doesn't vomit), the Feral (Left 4 Dead Hunter) and the Juggernaut (Killing Floor Fleshpound)

Cons:
-The tiny inventory started to get on my nerves though I suppose its more realistic, can't expect everyone to take 999 bullets with them every time.
-Being bombarded by silly requests when you're trying to do something gets REALLY frustrating.
-Only minor but unskippable intros (Microsoft Studios and Undead Labs thingies) are 800x600 regardless of resolution settings
-More minor stuff, when coming out of a menu if you try to move characters too fast they will only walk in a straight line regardless of other directional buttons pressed, and the fact changing character even if they are right next to you needs a loading screen, I can understand characters that are outside of base though.
-Drops in frame rates, specially while driving and getting to full speed even with graphical settings at minimum, I have 2xR9 270X, since its a mid ranged AMD product I'm not expecting it to rain gold and diamonds but jebus, the bloody framerate drops!!!
-No mouse support in menus, I hate these friggin ports that ignore the existance of this excellent creation which would make inventory management so much easier, BUT NO you MAY NOT make our job easier we NEED to make menus confusing.

The added content, I've noticed some of it like pallet swap cars, but to me it just seems like a Turtle Rock did it with Left 4 Dead!!" cash grab though I may be mistaken the further I get in. The game itself looks to me like a lot was put into it like the devs themselves cared for it so I don't really regret buying it

reviewText:
I really wish I could recommend this, because I really really loved the original one. I bought this game on a whim when I found out that I could import my save. To save time for others:

TL;DR: Save your money if you already have the original game, because the new content does not validate the price. If however you havent got the game at all, it is worth paying for as the old one is no longer available on steam.


Positive aspects:
-returning players from SoD get access to an exclusive player with the Nimble trait (reflexes)
-new type of car added that has an increased trunk space (6 spaces) with a bit less handling than a modern pickup, but more readily available and just as sturdy.
-like original SoD has intergrated controller support available
-returning players can import their save from SoD, breakdown and Lifeline
-Actions like creating more snacks and coffee are now available at the kitchen
-new mission type included in story type and breakdown, gives new lease of life to objects such as timers and talking dolls
-new map icons make it easier to see at a glance what kind of missions are available to you

Negative aspects:
-The game is really badly optimized. This particular game lags even on minimum specs
-Some zombies are not rendered correctly, and sometimes the buildings have the same problem. For machines (like mine) that ran original SoD perfectly fine, it seems like this is an issue that shouldn't have been one.
-the map looks less smooth and more boxy and cartoonish
-for the content that has been added ontop of the old version, it really is not worth the money even with the discount. The added features included in this pack, i would only realistcally pay around ¬£8 at most.
-No new voice actors have been commissioned. For when playing breakdown and the like, it can get tiresome to hear the same 6 voice actors over and over in different pitches.
-at times, attacks do not connect to the zombies, leading you to waste your stamina swinging wildly while they still come and wreck you.
-it is commonplace for your character to glitch into the foundations of the building. Whereas in the original SoD this glitch was only really common for zombies, the glitch has now expanded to affecting player characters
-the graphics as a whole just look sharp and horrible as if no edge smoothing has been used at all. in all honesty, I prefer the graphics of the old game.


Conclusion:
I will probably continue to play this game as i have already spent money on it, but looking back I wish I saw a review like this instead of the generic This is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• cash grab" so i could have just happily stayed with the original.
However
date: if you've never played State of Decay at all
hoursPlayed: and will recommend you buy this copy as the old one is now not available."

reviewText:
Pros:

A little better graphics (Almost no difference) & smoother frame rate.

Cons:

1. Aside from some graphic improvements & some pre-purchase bonuses, not much has changed in terms of gameplay & features.

2. Bugs are WORSE than the original version. Zombies pass through walls more frequently, cars flying, zombies flying, and still no one is manning the watch tower most of the time. I can overlook the bugs in the original game, but the larger number of bugs in YOSE edition is pathetic.

I don't know if it's caused by bugs, or the way the zombie AI is programmed, but zombies seem to know where you are from as far as 3 blocks away. I keep having my survivors killed due to being horded by dozens of zombies who just always know where I am sneaking around. I destroyed a bunch of zombies, and the other groups keep endlessly coming, until my survivors ran out of stamina and get killed. This is truly frustrating. I am unable to search items in the house without being surrounded by zombies from across the road who somehow know I am inside the house.

Even worse, the survivors who accompany me are dumb and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• pathetic. They just stand there getting mauled by zombies without fighting back. Seriously, what the F**k did the developers do to the AI ???

I have played the original SoD, and I will still go back to the original. The zombie AI is more balanced in the original game. The YOSE edition zombies somehow have human detector radar and you can never hide pass them. I keep losing my survivors and desperately look for new ones and train them, only to see them get killed as well. This totally ruins the gameplay. It's garbage.

reviewText: So I'll start off by saying I loved the original State of Decay game, I wrote a review on it a while back highly recommending it.  However, I can't recommend this game due to the fact that I feel it should have been an update rather than its own seperate game.  If you own State of Decay, Breakdown, and Lifeline, you have no reason to get this game.  The extra mission and character are not worth the $20 price tag.  The items it adds are basically the same items that already exist with a different skin making them worthless to the package.\n\nIf you don't have the original State of Decay game but were thinking of picking it up, this is a great value and, in that situation, I could recommend the game.  Otherwise, if you already own the games, steer clear of this game.

reviewText:
Okay so this is my first review on Steam. I loved SOD since I first heard the idea back in the day. I bought it on my Xbox (before I converted to the master race). It was innocent, a small company making the game everyone dreamed of. The concept was there, it made me feel for the characters when they were torn to shreds because I was too careless. It was an amazing game. The shoddy graphics and buggy gameplay were the only things hindering this beast of an idea. Everyday that I played this game I wanted to know what undead Labs was going to do to fix it. After a while I grew tired of waiting.

reviewText:
It's basically the same as the original one.

Different car reskins, different cars altogether. Some of the interface graphics have been improved. The icons on the map have been made a little bit bigger.

When you start Breakdown, you get five hordes right off the bat. With no outposts to fend them off, you have to find a couple of cars to get rid of them.  Then you're down a couple of vehicles because they've been ruined.

The same thing with Lifeline. You get rushed early in the game and you get overwhelmed. You're not given enough time to set up to fend them off properly.

The original campaign is the same, you go through the camp site and go on from there.

The zombie and the horde spawning can be a little bit too much at times. Everytime you try to search for something, they'll spawn outside the house. If you're in a field, they appear right in front of you. If you get out of a car to look for something, they'll be there next to the vehicle.

I'm all for killing the damn things, but it gets to be annoying after a while. It's still a good game, but it's still rough around the edges.

reviewText:
The  original State of Decay was a combination of everything i wanted from a zombie survival game. Building a community, scavenging resources and improving your living conditions during an apocalypse. It had it's own charm and all the annoying things about it (especially the bugs) were tolerable when you considered how small a developer Undead Labs was.
Yet i can not recommend this version of the game to anyone, not even people who haven't played the non-remastered" version.

The original version got rid of a lot of bugs through patching but most of those are back in the YOSE edition with the addition of way more annoying new ones (car hit detection where you drive through a whole zombie horde without hurting a single one). A lot of obvious design flaws were not corrected (like adding a simple sorting function to your base inventory) and the visual improvements are nice in comparison but not that noticeable. And for a "polished" version
recommended: even on a decent system.\n\nI ended up reinstalling the original SoD
hoursPlayed: since it has fewer bugs and a lot of awesome mods available

reviewText:
I played the first  State of Decay and the expansions for over 400 hours because I really liked the game. I admit that much can be improved and I was hoping YOSE would be a step in the right direction so I bought it even though they only gave a 33% reduction for a game that was only marginally improved.
However I can't play YOSE because the game crashes my pc.  I play for a random timespan then the screen goes black and poof the pc reboots.  I tweaked settings, updated the drivers and checked everything. No matter what: my pc crashes.
My pc is 3 years old and made for rendering movies, which is a pretty intensive process but even when rendering, playing a game, running you tube and various programs at the same time my pc won't crash. I also played a wide range of games  such as Skyrim but only State of Decay causes my pc to crash.
As this takes the fun out of the game and  I don't like my pc crashing to the point of no longer functioning I can't continue to tweak and play this game in the hope it won't happen again. And since most reviews confirm that the changes are superficial I can not recommend YOSE based on my experiences.
I would also remark that selling a game with almost no viable changes for almost the same price is tantamount to a rip off. But we are now doggy trained to the anything-for-a-profit argument so I guess this signifies the normal pattern in game development. You can see this with the early access  games that never get into full release. At first the idea was to give players the chance to help develop the game, but people quickly saw another way to make a profit: selling unfinished software that does not get into finished state because it is still under development". Examples are such games as  DayZ and Take on Mars from Bohemia Interactive Simulations
date: both almost 2 years in early access without a release date.\nI would advise people not to join the early access release racket. It gives bad companies methods to rip people off
recommended: it makes good companies lazy: they use you for what they should do themselves: properly develop software. And then  finallly they charge you again when the game is released in full.  Yes

reviewText:
New stuff:

-New cars and car skins
-New survivors and lifeline characters can be played in breakdown
-New Incindiary shotgun
-All weapons in this game can be played in all game modes (breakdown,vanilla and lifeline)
-New mission named Cleo

There are still bugs and issues from SOD that still exist in this game:

-No one is in the watch tower even though someone is assigned this happen often especially in Snyder Warehouse
-Survivors ignore the zombies even though they are already inside the base!
-Zombies getting stucked for some reason
-Random crashes and now more crashes than vanilla version
-Survivors nagging about there is not enough materials but actually there is more than enough to build a structure or two
-Zombies that were burned to death only shows animation but no fire effect sometimes when using incindiary rounds
-Zombie claw attacks penetrate doors
-Zombies and players still pass through walled objects and bounce back to their original place like an elastic effect (this happens especially in melee combat inside structures)
-Ai still blocks doors when idle
-Ai still attacks bloaters in melee
-Zombies can climb though barbed fence (this happens in kirkman residence)
-Animation issues when you roll over a group of zombies
-Zombies pass through walls
-Invisble flashlight (like the flash light is on yet survivors are not equipped with one and reminds me of old school CS)
-Unfixed exploit where in you get exp on guns when aiming on a zombie who is dying/died because of throwable items (grenade, petrol bomb and a like)
-Racksack becomes invisble when dropped and left for a certain duration however it can be still seen because of the marker of its contents and not the racksack itself
-History:Ran Away trait is persist and can be only fixed after getting sick
-Your progress in breakdown still progress even when you are not playing the game (the game is close/offline progress)and sometimes can cause death to your community if you did'nt finish some quest like locating a missing community member. There is no way you can disable this so far.
-If you have tons of weapons in your locker there is no way to sort things out (everything is unorganized and you need to find stuff  that you need manually which is a total eyesore)

And even new issues like:

-The game starts at windowed mode and solved by using alt+enter
-Alt tab will not really tab your window instead it will resize/restore the game
-You cannot adjust the graphics in an advance manner in such away that you can only adjust the gamma, resolution and video settings (low-ultra) and not things like shadow, anti-aliasing and so on
-Random FPS drop for some reason
-Undead labs claim that Facilities from Lifeline will be available in all versions of the game" however when I try to play breakdown I dont see this facilities as buildable structures like generator for example. Source: https://forums.undeadlabs.com/threads/everything-we-know-about-state-of-decay-year-one-survival-edition.47074/
-Zombies teleport when in focus aim
-Character change now has loading time for some reason
-Animation Issues when in combat at an elevated terrain (stairs for example) that causes animation issues sometimes
-Incindiary shotgun shells kills without flame effect does not count for phoenix achievement this happens when managed to kill a zombie at medium range or sometimes at a short distance
-Chemical Incindiary damage does not damage zombies immidiately and only triggers when you aggro them (this happens sometimes especially when undetected)
-Fires penetrate walls

Fixed issues from SOD version:

-Unresponsive ai combat system
-Pixelated blood/gore
-Not so dark when its evening compared to vanilla version making things more easier to see at night
-Improved effects like dust particles
date:
oil spill has now better texture and so many others
-Juggernauts are nerfed
-Ferals are now more dodgy
-Improved handling for old school muscle car
-Fixed issue on messed up shadows where the bomb is located at lifeline

Conclusion:

This game is meant to attract new players and as a returning player this is an epic face palm in my face because I am expecting a lot of bug fixes and less issues but instead its the other way around and the devs laziness shows in the game itself like you cant sort out weapons in the stoage
recommended: most issues/bugs unfixed and cant even adjust the advance video settings of this game. P.S. If the devs are reading this please don't take this personally but instead a wake up call to fix things up!"

reviewText:
To be honest, I've never expected that much from MMORPG developers trying to make single player sandbox community-building zombie survival game. Endlessly respawning zombies, poor AI, shallow story and primitive gameplay were inevitable, but there's more to it that could've been done right.

In the end, there are two points of view: as an xbox console game, even with all of it's flaws and drawbacks, it's a masterpiece not because it's good, but because there is no better alternative. As a PC gaming product, however, it can be described with a single word: mess. Literally none of the game's systems are working good enough. It's been nearly 2 years since original release and it didn't get any better.

You can build yourself a base of your liking but there are facilities that are essential to build and those that have completely negligible effects so there is never a choice. On a first glance your people seem to be a community but after a few days you realise that they're just a bunch of drones: they don't establish friend/enemy/couple relationships, events about fights, jealousy or interpersonal dislike are completely random and random community members are 'picked' to participate, when a community member dies two random members will get a morale hit etc so both base and community building aspects are a mess too.

What there remains? Hoarding? Your base stash has only 255 slots, so eventually you'll have to waste your time clearing it out every game day or two. Spent two hours gathering supplies to train your characters next day? Too bad, they got overwritten by your facilities' daily output and you have 5 items instead of 105. Character progression? Your favourites will get killed through a wall, when all floor two zombies fall through the ceiling while you're clearing first floor and tear you apart or your car turns over near two zombie hordes because someone inside farted.

In the end I can only recommend it as a cheap and glitchy Dead Rising substitute. However you probably should play Dead Rising itself instead.

P.S. Imagine yourself a grown up person that claims to be a skilled game developer. This person spends half an hour trying to get inside a blue public restroom and finally pisses oneself just because of being unable to realise that door opens outwards, not inwards. Pathetic? Definitely. Funny? Perhaps, but not so when you realise that it's your employee that you've sent half an hour ago to deliver some very urgent documents which had to be driven across town within 15 minutes or you'd lose a 1 million $ contract.

reviewText:
This is a hard one. I really really REALLY want to like this game. Its got all the elements for what should basically among the best zombie survival games ever. Usable cars, scavaging for loot and supplies, hundreds of weapons, base creation. But the massive set backs completely ruin this game. I'm not talking about the fact is basically the same game as the standard version. But instead things more key to the gameplay.

The main thing that ruins this game for me is just how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and useless the player controlled characters are. They usually cant do their automatically assigned jobs, most of them have no skills at all when you recuit them (apart from special heros), they wont use guns most of time, depending on what gun they have they usually cant effectively use it (seriously what the hell is wrong with ai and shotguns in this game), and none of them seem to understand the importance of always having someone on the watchtower (which as the main/only real defence your actual base has)  leaving you contantly open to attack. It doesnt sound like much but its just so frustrating when all your high level characters permadeath after spending hours training them up, just because they dicided to try to hit the massive boss zombie with a stick, rather than fire an assault rifle at it.

The scavenging on this game also feels like a waste of time, in most of my playthroughs i dont bother taking a lot of the supplies as the most common items are way to common, all my bases have enough food to open a supermarket after about 2 hours of playing, whereas materials are almost impossible to find. Along with other low level weapons, melee weapons and pistols are never usually worth picking up, and in most cases even bullets aren't even that worth encumbering yourself with as you typically only use rifle rounds, and after a few hours of play you can just make them yourself. With no console command or no weapons dealer the very rare guns are basically impossible to get. It really needs balancing and the supplies need to be better distributed.

Breakdown. The main DLC to play is a nice idea in theory but rapidly becomes boring. All that changed are the zombies slowly level up as you go. I cant believe theres 100 levels of breakdown, My personal best is 6, then i get bored and play something else. With no variation in levels you always start a level, loot the army bases looking for the rare guns, then build up which ever base is your favourite. Theres no side missions or random events to keep the levels fresh, its just a rinse and repeat affair. The only thing that keeps you going is the hope you stumfble along a new weapon, but its not really enough to base a game around.

All in all its a game that shows lots of promise but gets let down by a few massive issues that just sap the fun from the game.

reviewText:
I really want to love this game.  I had 50 hours on the previous version and I have logged 5 hours of what was supposed to be a really awesome SOD weekend for me.  There are a few perks to buying this game:
-The graphics are an improvement.
-There are a few bonuses for buying the YOSE edition.
-The game is based on one of my favorite games for the PC.

The problems that will make me not recommend this game:
-There are buggy zombies that appear to morph between/on top of/and around walls.
-I have had to restart my computer 15 times in the five hours that I have played!
-I have followed every direction on the dev's forum, on their own website, and on recommendation pages that I found on Google, and the longest I have been able to play without a restart is 30 minutes!

When I bought the original version of SOD I lived with the glitches because they, at worst, caused the game to crash and there was a fairly forgiving autosave, but this is ridiculous!  This project seems not to have addressed the most infuriating aspect of the original game.  How am I supposed to enjoy a game when I have to reset my PC every 20 minutes?  Then I get the joy of finding that one of the developer's solutions is to reduce the resolution of my monitor to 1280X720!  If one of the selling points of this patch was the resolution upgrade, why wasn't it taken into account that PC gamers would have high quality monitors?  Overall I will say that I am having a great time with this game, and if the dev offers a substantial update to help with stability issues, I will change my review, but I can't recommend that anyone buys this game without taking into consideration that you will have moments of mad fury when you are driving back to your home base and your screen suddenly jerks to a stop... try to remember where you were at your last autosave, because your truck (that was probably full of supplies) is probably still all the way out there.

For me, I will not play this game again until a patch comes through.  I regret spending the money on a studio that sold me a broken product.

reviewText:
I'm reviewing this game as someone who  DID NOT  play the original title. I understand people are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that they have to pay for this having already bought the original.

The best way of describing this game is that it's a mixture of Theme hospital(lol), gta, dead rising and DayZ. The gameplay mechanics are massively rewarding and the base upgrading and scavenging/looting system are really well done.

I've noticed quite a bit of clipping, lackluster textures for a PC title. and pretty shameful graphic options. On the Ultra preset it looks OKAY. you can expect to run it maxed out @ 60fps on the 6 series of Nvidia cards and above.
Driving feels pretty horrible after playing straight from GTA5 also.

The gameplay, progression system and rewarding base upgrading together with pretty satisfying combat makes the graphic niggles and driving not such of a big deal, though. Great game so far.

reviewText:
Here is a quick and simple review of 'State of Decay Year 1 Survival Edition'

Pro's
-----
The Frame rate has been raised to 60FPS so the gameplay is alot smoother.
The Resolution has been raised to 1080p so the gameplay is alot clearer.
The game bugs out alot less then the previous State of Decay game which for me crashed and stutered alot.
There are more vehicles and since the frama rate is higher you can appreciate them on the road alot more.
The game is cheaper starting today 11/06/2015 (Steam sale) then it was on day of launch even for the poeple who got the deal since they brouht the prviouse State of Decay Game.

Con's
------
Your having to pay ¬£22.99 for a updated version of a game you may have already played (Like myself)
The exclusive new charecter, car and weapons are only avalible to those who pre-ordered the game originally (bit silly you can't get them now)

Overall I did enjoy this new version of State of Decay, however I did feel the fact I had to pre-order to get the exclusive charcter (Which is a good charecter to use) was a little irritating and unfair. If I was ever to buy and Edition of State of Decay it would be this edition and I would recommend this edition to any new players over the original, espeshilly if there looking at getting any DLC at a same or later date. I hope this short yet sweet review helped your with an understanding for this game.

reviewText:
Consider this a first impressions. This review will be updated as I play more of it, yes despite this being a negative review I will be playing more of it.

So, how do I feel after playing the 'beautifully remastered' version of one of my favourite games? Rather disheartened and more than a little disappointed. Even within just over 30 minutes of gameplay I can see that not much has changed and by no means is this remastered.

If you already own the previous version then keep playing that. This so far offers not much in the way of improvement never mind anything new in the way of gameplay.

What I will say is that the trees look so much smoother and lighting is simply amazing compared to the original. Most textures are that bit smoother but where it really starts to fall apart is the people. I don't know if they look worse or if it is because the background looks better that the flaws/faults of their rather... clunky features just seems to shine through. Oh and for those who have played the previous version remember what a delight it was to have zombies clipping halfway through walls/windows and such? Yep. Still happening.

I realise I do not have that much time in this game but as somebody who has put in close to 100 hours into the original game and owns the DLCs for the original after half an hour I just feel rather disappointed and wished to warn those who have the game, do not pick this version of the game! For those of you who do not have the original and want to pick this game up, wait. Wait for half price or some decent patches because this 'remastered' game in its current state is not worth it.

reviewText: So all in all I enjoy this game. It has an interesting take and decent game mechanics. The game itself hits the zombie killing itch really well. There are some glitches here and there, but nothing I found to be game breaking. However, I've pretty much called it quits over one flaw. It randomly crashes. Not even gracefully. When it crashes randomly from what appears to be some graphical coding issue it gets trapped at a black screen. It is in full screen so it gets annoying trying to break it loose and kill the process. Not very difficult, but it really tries my patience. On principle I'm going to not recommend this game. Code hygiene is a basic. I understand crashing in mod-able games like with the TES series since things are more malleable by design. Even if a game has a crashing glitch it should at least redeem itself by way of a graceful CTD, and provide a crash dump to aid in troubleshooting.

reviewText:
I have to recommend this game. I cannot in good conscience not do so. You see, I came late to the party, and so bypassed the controversy that followed the release of this 'Year One Edition', which includes the dlcs Breakdown and Lifeline.

If you have not played State of Decay, then pay no attention to SOME of the reviews for this game, they are very much biased and tainted by that controversy that happened long ago which you can read more about in one of the other reviews I am sure.

This game has a lot going for it. It is very close to the type of zombie-game I was looking for for many years. An actionpacked 3rd person game, much in the style of some earlier 'GTAs', with a focus on base- and resource management.

Gather your group of survivors,  recruit new people, complete missions and interact with other survivor-groups. Scavenge for resources to use in upgrading and protecting your base and people; or move your entire base elsewhere on the map! All in a semi-open world yours to explore. Just be careful! Cars may break down, and if you get caught alone during the night by a horde be prepared to run!

A word about the dlc Lifeline. To some extent, I found this campaign to almost more enjoyable than the base game. Maybe it was just the setting, which is more urban and city-like in Flatline. The mechanics are the same, although you cannot move your base around in Flatline. This doesnt matter, as the base you start with has a lot of potential and is scene to some great defensive action. Call in snipers and air support as you try to defend your base of operations when the hordes get alerted to your presence, before gathering up your most experienced soldiers and go on a supply run, or try to rescue VIPs.

Also. State of Decay has permadeath for your survivors, and actions may have consequences. Be prepared to deal with it!

I experienced no bugs, crashes or any other technical issues worth mentioning with the game as of early 2016. No worries.

There arent many of these types of games in the 'zombie-genre', which I think is a shame. If you think the same, then I highly recommend Year One Edition to any newcomers.

All the best.

reviewText:
Since I absolutely loved the original game I wanted really badly to play this version of the game.
However, the performance is insanely unbearable. Stutters and fps drops are consistent.
I have waited months for some sort of noticable performance update or simply some better GFX settings beyond Low, Medium, High, and Maximum settings. But nothing.

This is the first game that I am actually considering trying to request a refund for. Compared to other games I play, there is just no excuse for this from State of Decay. If I can put countless hours into ports made by Ubisoft than Undead Labs and Microsoft Studios should be able to make something remotely playable.

And this whole rant was without even mentioning the fact that this version of the game holds nearly any difference to the original. The gameplay changes and visual improvements were incredibly minor. The greatest improvements were the integration of items and facilities between game modes/DLC. Something that should have been done originally from the contents release.

I've resorted to playing the original game again. Albeit with some spite.

reviewText:
Now that the original version of State of Decay is not available on Steam Store any more, it no longer makes sense to me to compare the two versions and try to make your point pro or against upgrading to YOSE. So, I deleted my previous review and wrote a new and more general one instead, mainly for those who are not yet familiar with State of Decay at all.
EDIT: The DLCs are still available for the original version, but the main game is not.

In my opinion, this is quite an underrated game in general, and to me the best zombie game I have purchased so far. I can't say that I'm a huge fan of the genre and have tried even nearly them all, but I have seen my share of gameplay for quite a few of them. Anyway, I feel that the user review aggregate doesn't do State of Decay itself as a game any justice, because of the controversy the YOSE edition caused with it's pricing weighed against it's added content which many felt was next to nonexistent.

First of all, I really like the combat system that actually has more depth to it than at first meets the eye. The variety of different melee and ranged weapons and the personal skills and abilities of different individuals make many different character builds viable and add to the replay value. The range of weapons is nicely complemented by the crafting possibilities of different explosive and incendiary weapons for horde control. Not to mention the use of different vehicles not only as a means of transport, but also as a quick and relatively safe way of  thinning out the densest ranks of zombies.

Yet the most compelling point to me is the importance of scavenging and resource management, which with different home base upgrades adds a strategic aspect to the game. Where to build your outposts, what resources to stack and how to best put them to use are questions you have to constantly ponder to best suit your preferred way of surviving. Chance also plays a role here as the composition of your group of survivors, their traits and proficiencies have an effect on which may be the most beneficial way to go on each playthrough.

I highly recommend this one to anyone who doesn't mind a bit of thinking and planning in addition of the merciless slaughter of the undead.

reviewText:
First off, this is a zombie game. Nothing like taking a pipe and whailing on an undead until your arm is tired.

That being said this game is horrible in every other regard. Asside from being dull as dish water its basically GTA/SR style games with zombies as cops. Seems fine except zombies spawn out of nowhere in an unending flood. You never feel a sense of accomplishment when you clear a building and 10 new ones spawn outside and come running in that werent anywhere nearby before. Houses seem to be zombie magnets, stay ouside in the fresh air and open fields where they cant get you. Clearly these where gamers before they died.

Questing is broken as can be often completely removing a side quest if a main one or new side decides to showup. Toggling the map to search for it turns up nothing.

AI is broken, while at times humorous, very annoying. God forbid you want to make a quick getaway while your partner tries to make up his mind what door he wants to get into deciding to take a leasurely stroll into the drivers side bumper for a few minutes while zombies run up, bend him over the hood and introduce him to prison ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. This is not a rare bug, this will happen almost any time they approach the front side of the vehicle you get into. Dont forget you can flip a car just by hitting a small bump cause the physics are garbage. Or you know. Decide outside the base is a great idea during a zombie seige.

Zombies will often glich out when climbing and shooting them has a good possibility of them just teleporting to the otherside for quick easy access to your yummy delicious flesh.

AI are stupid in the matter of guard towers, they dont use them even though they are avaliable. When they are an actual designated structure they often leave them unmanned because they are tired" and no one takes their place. Not that someone with a shotgun is any good at hitting anything further than the base of the tower anyways. Might as well be shooting cottonballs out of a shotgun if you're  further than shoving it down a zombie's throat.

Most item durability is a joke. Zombie hoard? Get in a car and run them over cause your generic tools wont last the fight
date:
firing a gun is a waste of time cause it just generates more zombie spawns.

My mind is still boggled how a small tri town of maybe 1000 residence can have so many zombies. The way I ran over zombie hoards I should have had the entire populous cleared in ten minutes.

On top of all this I felt bases were generically useless and left me with little customizing or results of what was there to the point I wondered why they even bothered. The lack of realism in any sense just left me laughing. Like a Juggernaught walking to the gate of a chainlink fence when it should be able to walk through. Or better yet. Lets board up these windows but not let us shoot through the boards instead the boards will break no matter where you shoot.

These are all lazy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• mechanics you expect 15 years ago."

reviewText:
From the screenshots, descriptions and reviews the game looked promising but I am quite disappointed:
The world feels empty, you can find items only in scavengeable locations, there are no drops from zombies. There are a lot of cars everywhere but all their trunks are empty.
There is no really any goal. You are being spammed with very repetitive missions (kill zombie/rescue survivors/clear location/scout area/collect resources). Within a few hours of gameplay you have the largest available base with all buildings constructed.
Except a few buildings' upgrades there are no upgrades in game. You cannot add weapon/armor to your car or craft and attach a scope to your weapon. You can attach silencers to weapons which are destroyed after 10/30/50 shots. You cannot detach silencer or replace is with a new one.
The world is small and easily accessible. One of the first missions is to drive to the other end of map which takes only a few minutes. Cars don't have fuel. They can blow up if you drive over zombies too much.
Poor choice of items. Melee weapons, range weapons, usables (medications and grenades) and that's it. There are no armors and an assault rifle takes same space in the inventory as 3 grenades. There are two types of backpacks giving you either 8 or 10 slots for items.
Weapons statistics are not shown. For melee weapons you have absolutely nothing other than it's cost. For range weapons there are a few icons but without any descriptions you have no idea what they mean.
AI of your fellow survivors is very poor. They will not attack zombie if it is rushing at them until it hits them. They often get stuck in buildings or are unable to get in cars. You may be just being killed by two zombies and they will be standing a few meters away and watching.
No save/load. Game saves automatically and if you die the character is gone, you can still play as another character though. I did not really enjoy having to copy save files.
The game is not prepared for multi-screen setups. It blacks out non primary screens. If you minimize it, it switches from fullscreen to window and there is no setting to switch it back. You have to search on forums for a magic alt+enter combination to bring it back to fullscreen, and this combination is not even in the controls. There is no borderless windowed mode.

reviewText:
What I think about this so called remaster

Honestly after playing about 15 mins of playing this I thought is was a complete waste of money and do not recommend purchasing this at all.

The so called graphics improvements are noticeable (if only the slightest) in what I think giving the game a more cartoony feel
From what I saw there was one new vehicle and some of the others had been remodeled/reskined, there were a couple of redesigned items and a fancier inventory, survivors, home management screen
I all so think there were a couple of new zombie animations and the airdrops are a nice addition but honestly this is only really worth being a $5 dlc for the original game which I thought was one of the best zombies games I've played in a long time

But if you have already played the first game and found it very enjoyable or your new to SOD and looking for a great game to play, you may forgive the $20-30 dollar price that is asked for this but
I diden't

In Short
Audio - Hasn't changed
Visuals - Slightly Improved
Gameplay - only a few little additions

overall, this is not worth the price that it is currently selling for

(Edited because someone wasn't happy with me trying to save the person reading this some money)

reviewText:
In spite of the glitches and diamond-in-the-rough quality, I am a big fan of the original State of Decay on Steam. To play it with fewer glitches, a few new moves, and a few new cars was completely worth the $20 (for a previous owner) cost of admission. However, I regret it now. It refuses to play properly on my system no matter how I tweek the resolution and other graph settings. It chugs and sticks and isn't even as smooth as the first edition. For me, it's been unplayable.  From the start, at the ranger station, I lost voices before Ed was attacked. There were times when I couldn't gather the duffle of supplies.

There were some other changes to expect that were not present previously, and they that are debatable changes. There are many more zombies. It is difficult to accomplish missions because of the additional hordes. Driving a car creates zombie pride day every moment. They swarm at the sound of a vehicle. Stealth walking is the only way to travel in peace. Infestations are much bigger.

They could have fixed the glitches. They could have added just a little new dialog and a few new voices. They could have made it playable without the chugs and lack of control from the frame rate slow downs (Saving Maya a gruesome death stating right next to a car door). Instead, they took my $20 and gave me an unplayable game.

Thanks Undead Labs.

reviewerDisplayName: S Y P H O N F i L T E R
reviewText:
I felt compelled to write this review after my experience discovering this game, reading the reviews and the backstory of it, deciding not to buy it, coming back, deciding to bite the bullet and buy it, and my thoughts on playing it so far.

First of all I do think it's a pretty ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• thing that the developers did, making their earliest diehard supporters purchase the entire game again and going as far as to disable the old version of the game. I think that's a really sheisty move and makes no sense. It'd be one thing to release this version here and ask for everyone to pay again, but forcing fans of the game to buy it again is really not cool at all. Because of this I almost did not buy the game. I hope they learned their lesson and don't try to pull a move like this again, they're lucky it didn't get more press coverage too because it could've buried this game.


Now on to the review. I'm not as much of a zombie games fan as I am an open-world game fiend. I love any and all open world games, and that's how I came across this one. It looked like a more fine-tuned, less minecraft-ish version of 7 Days to Die, and I watched some videos on it and thought it looked cool.

So I purchase the game and start playing. First of all, the resolutions are weird. You may not be able play in your own native resolution, you just have a choice of different ones to play in, unfortunately for my 2560x1440 (27 inch) monitor, I was ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of luck, as the game skips from 1690* all the way up to something like 3820*.

I understand that the game was just remastered to 1080p so I figure whatever.

Start up the game.

I find myself in a camp with my friend. I bash the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of some zombies, free us up, head for a cabin to meet someone etc. bash more zombies, check around for supplies. It seems a little bit simple so far.

But then it started to click. The sun was going down and everything had a warm orange glow like a summer sunset should look like. I was cruising with my friend to the place we were headed, it was a long country road that had gas stations and agricultural warehouses etc. I would pull up to these, hop out of my car, go inside and collect the resources. My backpack could not fit everything -- the game is not like Skyrim where your character can practically carry a room full of stuff on his person. Instead, you have to either carry what you can, or find a vehicle and use it as your 'mule' you can load up the trunk with items.

So I'm loading up my car as the sun is going down and I was like hmm this is cool. This feels kind of real. It feels immersive, despite the arcade-action hack and slash bash em up mechanics, theres something very immersive about the game, you can get lost in it if you use your imagination.

Finally my car is packed up and I head to the base I've been told to go to. I get there and I'm greeted by the voice on the CB radio but it's her in person. The sun is just about fully set as I'm having a tense conversation with the leader of the new base. I'm walking from my car into the base, making a few trips to unload all the supplies into the base's main supply hub (which sort of works as an auto-sorter and you get 'influence' which is like currency for withdrawing from the supply closet or building/fixing addons for your base in return)

That's when I was hooked. It felt so real, like that feeling you get when you make a long road trip and you get to your family member or friends home in the night time, unpacking the trunk of the car as you're catching up with them. The dusk was a pretty shade of orange-ish gray and it really caught my eye.

The night set. I decided hey, this is the zombie apocalypse there's no time for sleeping.

SO I opened the gate of the base and set out into the village. I kept myself crouched and moved ultra slow. You don't want to horse around in this game, if your character dies, they die FOREVER. They're GONE. You can go back and get their supplies but all of the leveling up and skills and everything you build up is washed away for good. This makes the game SO much better and more immersive IMO. You really don't want to lose a character. I was moving so slow, peering around corners of buildings.

The villages are set up very nicely, yards are yards, the houses are a good distance from each other and everything looks and is laid out in a nice fashion to where it looks exactly like some of the little rural villages that are outside of my city around here. They did a nice job on all of that.

There are some minor clipping bugs. The zombies can get stuck in corners or your character can, and that can be pretty annoying. The save function is a little strange too, it just seems to save on its own from time to time or after some type of event. Sometimes I'm not sure when it's saved or not.

Hint: It WILL NOT SAVE THE GAME if you are on a mission.

Hint #2: OPENING YOUR MAP OR INVENTORY DOES NOT PAUSE THE GAME! I learned that the hard way. RIP Paul.

The DLC expansions come free with the game. I haven't gotten far into Lifeline DLC yet but it's an urban setting and you're in the military so you start off in a military base and you're loaded to the teeth with weaponry and gear.

The Breakdown setting is one I've really been having fun with. It's basically the same sort of gist as the regular game but there's no set storyline, it's an infinite sandbox where things keep popping up that you can do, you need to keep getting supplies and upgrading, and the zombie population that's lurking around the city and the hordes that start to gather and patrol the areas just keep getting stronger in numbers.

Overall, it's not the most perfect game ever but I am having a ton of fun in it. I really think it's worth the $30. It's an enjoyable experience with 3 different modes and tons of replayability with the infinite sandbox mode. I have one game going where I am dead center in the bigger town in the south, right in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and then I have one game going where I'm in the center of the map in the vast expansive rural farm region, a nice farmhosue and I hop in my pickup truck to make runs in the morning and pull back in at night. It's a cool game.

reviewText:
Please bear in mind this review was left at the time of release and may be out of date. I cannot change the review because I no longer own the game (had it refunded/removed). If the bugs have been resolved, great, but my review will remain the same, just remember it's out of date so take it with a pinch of salt.

I don't often leave reviews. If I do it's either a) the game is fantastic beyond words or b) the game is so awful that people need to be warned to stay away.

This is nothing but a cash grab, and not even a remotely good one at that.

I can't comment on the game itself, because I've not played it. I've not played it because I can't face playing it due to the many pre-game play bugs I've already encountered within the first 5 minutes of loading, which are ruining it for me.

It's 2015. Yet this 'remastered' 'game' is worse than the original - wow!

I have a brilliant computer, which far exceeds the top end specs for this game. My monitor is not great, it gives off a lot of glare because of the material the screen is made from. Therefore I use a 7 year old matt-effect monitor, made from a similar material to the screens of the paperwhite Kindles, resulting in next to no glare or migraines.

This 'remastered' game looks no different to the original, despite my graphics card being 3 times better than the machine I had when I played the original release. The 1440 x 900 resolution I use for every other game I have (and without issue), isn't supported by this game. Yes it's in the list of resolutions, but if you actually choose 1440 x 900, you're greeted to lines around the screen (no fullscreen), about 1.5 inches of the game screen not being viewable, going off the right side of the screen, and the task bar constantly shows up and superimposes over the 'not fullscreen fullscreen.' Pressing alt+return to force 'fullscreen' works, until randomly your taskbar superimposes over the top.

I'm a little OCD, so I can't play a game with 1.5-2 inches of the gameplay off the side of the visible monitor. Games shouldn't be released like this in 2015. I've tried all of the staff suggestions and none of them have provided a satisfactory screen/resolution or fixed the 1440 x 900 issue, which they haven't even agreed is a bug yet.

Multiple complaints on their forums about resolutions and they release a bug fix patch neglecting the resolutions issues.

For almost a month people complained about resolution incompatibilities and nothing was done. Poor service.

Avoid until they a) fix the many bugs and b) offer some additional content. The 'remastered' features are not, I repeat not, worth buying this for.

I no longer own the game, removed/refunded.

reviewText:
You will enjoy this game for at least 10 hours I assume.  After that you be wondering how this amazing game got so lost.

Lets start with the good:
-Graphics are well done, buildings and houses and car mechanics all great.
-It's a sandbox game and has base building.
-Game controls are fairly easy to use and generally work well.
-Zombies" are realistic and can have a slight jump factor.

CONS:
-Gets old fast.
-you will constantly be having to go out and rescue people that wander off your base or be forced to settle disputes within your people almost constanty.
-You can never have more than one person with you at a time except for very limited "quest" circumstances.
-Resources are not infinite and neither are cars "although they can be fixed".
-"Special Zombies" can be tough at times.. you come out of a house and haven't saved in awhile and one of the huge zombies kills you.. well you're dead and that's it.  You just lost that person that you could have had since day one and was your best player.
-WHEN YOU LOG OUT THE GAME KEEPS PLAYING... so when you log back in some people could be gone or heaven forbid dead and your resources will be gone just about.  The longer you are logged out for the worse it is.
-Story is hardly worth bothering with.. it's mundane at best.

How this game should be:
-Open world sandbox.
-Single player good story.
-YOU pick the teams that go out and scavenge for food and tell them where and when to go.
-Make parties bigger than just a small group of 2.
-get rid of all the annoying distress signals "your people only leave the base if you tell them to"
-Need more materials in more places so you can play longer.
-Have more freedom on basebuilding and job assignments.

Do I think you wil enjoy this game? Sure but there is no way I can recommend this game for 30$ wait till it is 75% off before you even think about it.  I wanted to love this game.. sad.. really dissapointed stupid distress signals.. completely ruin the game."

reviewText:
I'll leave a link to the review for the original SoD Review I made: http://steamcommunity.com/id/ktg123/recommended/241540

But for the Year One Edtion? I can say that I can't fully reccommend this game. This being a follow-up to the original game, it basically upgrades itself in terms of graphics, and gives you the DLC in the full game. But what is wrong with this game is the amount of bugs it has and the same problems I mentioned in the linked review above. Now the game is still good, don't get me wrong, but the bugs just ruin it sadly. I would say buy the original version, but it seems you cannot do so anymore.

Don't let this review (or any other review) skew your judgement on this game. Only you can figure it out yourself, unless you like to go by reviews or gameplay videos on Youtube. Either way, it's your judgement call on this game, readers.

reviewText:
State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition
This game is incomplete

Since back then in 2013 I really wanted to have this game. At the last sale I finally got myself to buying it. From what I had read during this long period of time, I had very high expectations. State of Decay managed to excel them.

I have played for 11 hours until now and I have thoroughly enjoyed them. I wouldn't say this is the definitive zombie game but yet it is the best one I have ever played (it was my first zombie game ever xD).

The core gameplay is real fun. You stroll around a pretty big map and try to survive somehow: you collect food/materials, you upgrade your home base, you make sure your crew stays motivated. Later on you even fight against various diseases who kill you almost instantly. Overall, it's very satisfying. Although it feels a lot like babysitting the dumb AI at the beginning, you learn to appreciate that the game always keeps you busy.

Nevertheless, there are a few negative aspects which affect your experience badly.
1. Glitches. Be it zombies under floors/zombies in walls or backpacks also under the floor.
2, Lack of personalisation. You basically stay forever with the basic appearance survivors have by default.
3. The ridiculous real-time-feature. I mean srsly, bros at Undead Labs?? All types of materials you can collect in this game decrease daily. Which means you would have to play more or less everyday in order to provide yourself and your crew a functioning home base. This isn't motivational, it is f*****g annoying and also f*****g ridiculous!

I can't play everyday and so I decided to leave Story Mode alone and try the endless Lifeline"-mode. I'll probably come back to the story someday
date: but I just don't understand the reason they built in this feature.\n\nSummarized
recommended: I hope there will be a sequel at some time
voteText:
please don't let it have this ridiculous feature I mentioned above. I'm looking forward to playing DayZ.

7/10
Good Game
