reviewText:
Short version:

Standard Edition Owned = 5/10 - Skip it (unless making ammo in Breakdown is essential for you)

No Version Owned = 8/10 - A really great zombie game with some slight RPG elements and a solid survival feel.


Long Version:

Having put a metric ton of hours into both this version and the old version, I can with confidence say there are some significant differences between the two.  Firstly, the actual entire reason I bought the YOSE version after having bought and played the standard version is that you can have the Munition shops now make ammunition in both the base game as well as breakdown.  This alone makes a significant difference in the gameplay experience, if you are one of those who enjoying going through all the levels of Breakdown.  It makes skilling your survivors out in guns skills actually worth it, which is something I wanted desparately from the start.  However, this REALLY should have been a free update rather than a whole new buy.  This fact alone makes this a hard pill to swallow and has made me question if I would buy anything from this company again.

Graphics are much improved, however stuttering is still a big problem, mainly when driving around at high speeds.  This is particularly noticable in Lifeline as there is a lot of smoke and fire effects with most of the map being highway full of burning wrecks.  You need to have a beefy system, quite a bit more than even the minimum specs as it doesn't appear to be well optimized for PC (surprise surprise).  Even with an 8 core with 24 gigs of RAM and various Gforce 900 series cards, I still get significant framerate drops while driving around.  However, it is still impressive given there are no loading screens for the quite large open map.

Still, it looks nicer that the standard edition, but runs worse.

As I said, you can now craft ammunition in breakdown and the base game, which is a game changer (for me anyway).  You can make snacks and coffee in the kitchen now as well.  A few more vehicles have been added like the Army truck from Lifeline is now available in Breakdown, as well as the ability to repair your vehicles in Lifeline, which is nice, not having to just ditch the Army trucks when they start smoking anymore.

For me, most of the bugs from the old version have been cleared up, but some new different bugs have been introduced which can be just as annoying.  No more driving at full speed and then for no reason the physics engine decides it wants you to visit the moon, and launches you  500 feet into the air.  Your survivor then automatically bails out of the car mid flight, and you get to watch as one of your best survivors plummets to their death with nothing you can do but watch in utter horror.  Now however, doors/gates seem to offer very little benefit  with stopping zombies, since about 50-75% of the time, they just walk right through them, which can make things particularly frustrating (and deadly) in Lifeline sieges.

So all in all you get a cleaner interface, some animation changes (blades skill animation has been tweeked slightly), better graphics, a few (very nice) guns, some olds bugs replaced by new bugs, the ability to craft ammo, snacks, and coffee, and some new survivors (Lifeline characters have been added to Breakdown).  If you own the standard game, and none of the things mentioned interest you, then I'd say give this one a pass.  If you don't own the standard copy and like zombie games, then I would absolutely recommend you get this version.

reviewText:
State of Decay was originally released in 2013 on the Xbox 360 and PC and two years later in 2015 we have a remaster known as Year One Survival Edition. I originally played the game in 2014 on my Xbox 360 and had hours to spend on it. I decided to buy the PC version when a new version of State of Decay was released, but the original version was taken off steam. I'm going to be reviewing the actual game itself, if you want to know the difference between this remaster or the original, then these are the differences. The game has been remastered, so that just means better graphics, less bugs and problems and more smooth gameplay, and the game has ticked all those boxes. But the most notable difference is that this version contains all the DLCs for free. If you have already got the original State of Decay on your PC, then I do not reccommed you buy this. Unless you want the DLCs and improvments to the original and you're willing to pay ¬£23 or around $30 for this, just stick with the original.

Onto the actual game itself, you start off at a fishing lake getting attacked by zombies or as they though it was 'a cannibal family picnic'. You end up at a police building where you meet some other survivors. You and your friend, 'Ed' search houses and find a woman who's friends were killed. Eventually you make it out of the mountains and into a town where you meet a girld called 'Lilly' who you met on a radio. After that, you have your own free will to do whatever you feel. The story is slightly bare as the cutscenes are just as advanced as the camera system you have when you're still playing. But the gameplay is what makes State of Decay so good.

No other game is like State of Decay, it's a bit like  a mix of GTAV, DayZ and Telltale's The Walking Dead. If that appeals to you, you will love this. As the game is open world, you can go anywhere in the Trumbull county. There are several towns to explore and lots of long countryside roads, but you will spendf most of your time inside the town your base is in and looting it. There are some vehicals to drive which you will probably blow up in 10 minutes and attract a load of zombies and there are tons of buildings to loot. But knowing where to start is up to you. This game makes you make choises by your own instinct.

Combat is very well designed when your attacked by zombies. You wack them with a mele weapon or just beat them to death. One zombie is easy, even ith no weapons and low stamina, you could take one on and not lose any health, but when your attacked by a dozen, it gets hard. You will automitically lock onto the zombie your facing and repeatedly smash it until it's head breaks. But when another zombie attacks you from behind, it will jump on you forcing you to try and shake it off. One thing to know is that this game is slightly over the top with gore. You can sneak up on a zombie and kill it by grabbing onto the head and smashing it on the the floor. Not to mention this game has some finshing moves that look badass. In terms of weapons, you have a lot but only really two types of mele weapons. If your using things like hammers, hatchets, cricket bats, you do quick slashes on zombies that take about five hits. But if you use big sledgehammers or an axe then you will do big swings at the zombies taking only three hits, but more time. This is simular to Skyrim with one and two handed weapons.

In terms of guns, they nail this too. You will often be scrounging for weapons, and you may come across a gun shop or police department, in that case, bingo! Because guns are very useful in some cases, in some missions you will have to protect NPCs from zombies by barricading houses and attacking the zombies. Often you are left with no choice but to shoot some, especially some of the 'freak' zombies. When you scavenge for ammo, you will not find a lot, making every shot count. You can get many guns, pistols, rifels, assult rifels, shotguns, even grenade launchers (not common).

AI is alright, the zombies aren't meant to be Einstein so they are pretty easy to sneak past when you are crouching. But when your trying to survive the apocalypes, you may make a lot of noise, and this noise willcertainly attract zombies. Shooting, driving, running, jumping, fighting, scavenging will lure zombies towards you, which can be difficult because you will be doing a lot of the previously listed activities. This is also useful when you need to make a distraction, using firecrackers will make lots of noise, attracting zombies in the area so you can get past or loot. The actual zombies come in many forms, some are stronger than others but the strongest are the 'freaks'. These zombies are much more tough or deadly, especially juggernauts. These are huge zombies with look like they have mixed DNA with a bear and tank, these are incredibly hard to kill.

Your community is controlled by you and your influence. Influence is kind of a 'symbolic currency' in your community which you can use to spend on different things. You can ask to find supplies or make outposts where you can store supplies or make facilities in your base, the concept is very useful. You earn influence by doing missions such as saving people, finding people, finding supplies, killing 'freaks', looting houses, talking to people and other activities. Your community also needs to feel safe, so that means you need lots of supplies and not a lot of zombies in your town, and no infestations. These are a sort of nest for zombies where they live and eat and if you don't clear infestations, your community may slowly fall apart.

You can find new members to join your community to help you survive, but this also means another mouth to feed, and supplies are rare once you have scavenged most of them. Your map shows the whole of Trumbull county and has crosses on the houses you have already scavenged. So sooner or later you will need to find a way to escape Trumbull county by following the main missions which lead to an alright story, what you would expect off a zombie survival game. I personaly had no problem with the ending, but I know many found it dissapointig. But this is a spoiler free review so I will not say anything else.

There are several vehicals to drive, but as I previously mentioned they tend to be about as safe as petrol and fire. Some vehicals are big and protected with a lot of space to store supllies and some are small and fast with little protection. One thing to note is that youi can change your character to go on house raids or when your character dies you can change to another member of your community, and then find the supplies of your last character. This game also has a very nice soundtrack along with very nice graphics. I remember the first time I tried to go on a scavenge in State of Decay was at night and I was too worried to fight the zombies in case it attracted more. So I was just sneaking from bush to bush, hiding from the zombies, along with the beautiful soundtrack.

But like most games, I do still have my fair froblems with the game. First, you don't really feel any connection to the other members of your community, when another member joins, it just means less space but more help. The only characters I ever really cared for were Marcus (the character you start with), Lilly, Ed (your friend at the beggining) and Maya (another early character you meet). And the game is slightly buggy. It doesn't feel very polished at times, but this is easily passable by the fun gameplay itself.

Overall, if your looking for a zombie survival game that isn't just buggy multiplayer or the slaughter of millions of zombies, I can't reccommend this to you enough. Despite the lack of polish this game has, you will get hours of fun from it.
9/10 Not a masterpiece, but real damn close!

reviewText: Another game in the recent zombie survival genre explosion, State of Decay is one that plays more action/adventure rather than horror survival like many other recent examples.  Despite frequent strange gameplay bugs and some oftimes frustrating camera movement, SoD is a stellar, and more importantly FUN, game.  The three different modes of play keep things interesting and allow for lots of replay value.  All in all, I highly recommend it if you enjoy both the genre and third-person action/adventure games.

reviewText:
things can get overwhelming with the amount of stuff you have to do!. you cant do everything in the game sadly you have 2 be wise in your choices of mission priorities, also keeping certain characters alive opens up new quests to them but if they die you cant finsh that quest thers always sumthin goin on its intense! either you are rescuing surviors, helping defend neighbours, scavenging for supplies or parts to complete a facility, seting up outposts, clearing out infestations, killing a certain zombie type in community 2 keep neighbourhood safe, building up your base etc etc alot goin down defo, and ontop o that u have 2 survive while doing all of this!! this has to be one of the most biggest maps i seen on any zombie game period!! it makes moon map on call of duty look tiny haha. If you bought the previous version of this game you get preppers pack & a new character a suv and some weapons. This game does make you think before you go out on runs i.e stocking up on meds weapons & guns/ammo etc.Alot of people have said this game should be coop its got all the makings of coop. you can play this game for hours literally there is a few character tweaks u can try for a challenge i suppose i.e reflex + heavy weapons. There are bugs in it but some make you laugh others look stupid but gameplay outweighs the bugs imo its got smooth gameplay also you have to be accurate when doing melee attacks because hitting them on stairs or hills you can miss swings/hits on them.

ZOMBIES IN THE GAME
Normal (4 -5 different types) /  FERAL /  SWAT / POLICE / SCREAMERS / JUGGERNAUT / BLOATER / INFECTED.

id reccomend this game to any hardcore zombie gamer even has a hardcore mode (breakdown dlc)
the game has 3 game modes: Story Campaign (SODYO), Campaign hardcore (BREAKDOWN) and  Army story (LIFELINE)

iSOD YOSE you play through the story rescuing survivors along the way  build up ur base etc
BREAKDOWN there is no story but your own you make all the choices and survive as long as you can
LIFELINE you play as army soldiers and play through a story extracting VIP'S and defending your base from zombie hordes and learn of how the infection began. YOSE & BREAKDOWN are the same map in YOSE you are inclined to move to the warehouse whilst in BREAKDOWN you can choose anywere you want build up the area then escape.

id give this game a 88 outta 100   (8.8 - 9)
if it had coop then a 93/4 outa 100 (9.3/4)

Really fun over the shoulder zombie shooter with long term survival as the driving element, this game feels like a combination of Grand Theft Auto and Killing Floor.

I'd recommend this game to pretty much anybody who enjoys zombies.

reviewText:
Probably the best zombie survival game out there. It has an open world feel in a town setting which helps immensely in making the town feel real. It was a surreal feeling as i was starting to learn the roads and ways to get back home recognising signs and houses as i drove by them while mowing down zombie hordes.

Cars really make a difference making missions play out faster and a little safer though still quite dangerous especially when your vehicle has no driver side door allowing a zombie to pull you out of your car to make a flesh dinner out of you if you dont toss em off somehow. Having a car makes mowing down zombies which have formed a horde much more easier to tackle compared to the much more terrifying on foot melee combat. You will have many different types of vehicles at your disposal which feel great to drive and have a nice collision model with some good visuals showing car damage until eventually you have to abandon it as it begins to smoke eventually catching on fire. You can though with the proper base upgrades repair vehicles before they get too banged up.

Of course you can always walk it which makes things much more dangerous as you have to bring food to keep your stamina up and medicine to deal with any possible injuries while evading any large gathering of zombies as the day fades into the night. You can defend yourself with melee weapons for close up combat and guns for long range attacks. You will be limited by what you can carry especially with supply stockpiles you come across but this can be remedied by using a vehicle for supply runs which allows you to load up multiple stockpiles to take back to the base where your friends and other survivors are.

Going through houses and commercial buildings for supplies and survivors is creepy as you never know if there is just that one zombie you see slowly moving past a first floor window or if the place is infested by zombies in other parts of the house. With some stealthy movement you can scout the outside of the house looking into windows to get a possible idea of what awaits inside. That is unless a zombie sneaks up behind you as you struggle with it attracting the zombies in the house. Next thing you know the stealthy silence is shattered by an explosion of zombie moans and growls raging with crazed cannibalistic hunger for your warm raw flesh.

Gathering supplies is needed to build your base and upgrade it over time allowing it to have more survivors living there while better dealing with the psychotic murderous zombies roaming the country side. Gathering supplies which are used daily, completing missions, bringing new survivors, keeping things peaceful between fellow survivors, cooking a nice big meal, brewing up a pot of delicious hot coffee among many other things helps to keep morale up at your home base. You will also gain influence points and fame which allows you to choose better equipment from the supply store and influence others to help you.

You will be playing more then one character as you do missions you will become tired over time and need to rest. This is when another survivor can be asked to take the place of your current character out on the field while they rest up. As your characters grow and develop you will find yourself getting attached to them. When my characters died i was surprised just how it effected me and actually missed them afterwards feeling the loss along with people back at the base talking about their death.

They also died in some incredibly blood thirsty gruesome ways which shocked even a gore hound such as myself. It felt strangely sad as another survivor i was playing came across my previous now dead character's backpack full of supplies as they picked it up to take back to base.

The excellent journal log keeps tracks of all these events and effect it has on everyone. It is also used to give orders for things like base upgrades, seeing what quests are available and things like how other survivors are getting along with each other and the morale of the base.

Weapons and vehicles can be repaired when the proper base upgrades are built. This is usually over night so it pays to use more then one type while the other is being repaired.

Music is done very well setting the tone of a once normal world transformed into a unbelievable living nightmare which blends well with the home town family surroundings all around you constantly assaulting your mind with contrasting atrocities of flesh eating zombies feasting on the living.

Graphics are interesting in the fact that they are not the greatest yet get the point across like a sledgehammer as you are suddenly witnessed to a brutal death and even more shockingly so if its your own.

STATE OF DECAY: YOSE Day One Edition if i could call it one thing it would be the perfect George Romero's NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD simulator capturing a normal if not blissful country setting where unbelievable horror is occuring.

reviewText:
Still one of the best of its type out there.
*Has base building and people management(you can only control one person at a time).
*Resource gathering seem like an adventure in itself.
*Unique skills and traits that heroes and sometimes other survivors will have when you acquire them.
*Later levels which feature more dangerous zombies like Ferals and Juggernauts are pretty exciting(also they are now more dangerous as compared to the first version of the game).

The campaign seem more of a tutorial on how to play it. The other two modes, Lifeline and Breakdown are the main meat of this game. The campaign is great for the first playthrough.  I really like the story. But after that, there is really no point in replaying it other than exploring one or two alternate consequences for your decisions which is nothing major. The main ending will still be the same.

Odd stuff:

*Characters have rpg type elements added to them like shooting skills and melee skills, and also stealth skills. Some of these skills takes a long time to develop and seems out of place for a game where you can't control whether the character will meet their death(causes like depression, sickness, or getting killed by other chars).

*Some bugs like zombies occupying the same space as a fence or a wall(common) and at times can walk through doors(uncommon) have not been fixed since the very first version of this game.

Overall I'd still recommend this game as the good experience I've had with it is far more than the few annoyance with it.

reviewText: Please do not be turned off by the negative reviews. If you think its a bad game because of them, you need to reconsider. The game is very good in itself, ive played nearly 200 hours of it for the xbox 360. Most of the negative reviews are only from people who are dissapointed that it is not too different from the original. The new version of the game includes new vehicles, survivors, missions, and a pretty nice graphics remake. While this doesnt add up to be TOO much content, its enough to keep the game fresh. Even in its own, the game does not get boring easily. Plus, the fact that it comes with both of the DLC for the game justs the price. Its kind of dissapointing when I see people hating against the game as a whole because the update wasnt that impactful, and they dont even realize that the price comes with the DLC included. If you have never played the game before, and like zombie games, I highly reccomend that you try it out. I got the game for 360, played 200 hours, and decided to buy it again for the PC.

reviewText: Overall I think that people just enjoy hating on this game. After 10+ hours of playing the game I decided to make a review.\n\nThe game starts you off in a post apocalyptic world where you can do anything you want, whenever you want. After the first 5 hours you will notice that the morale missions are the most repetitive and boring part of he game, they come about every 29 minutes and the game will be effected if you do not do them. Theses morale missions" also have he same script so don't expect any variety with them. Other than that you will have a blast with this game. The searching and horde mechanics add soo much adrenaline and stress
date: making you plan out every move. At the start your main weapon will be your car but after a while you will move into all types of weapons.\n\nThe base building aspect of the game is one of its strongest
recommended:
you can decide to build all sorts of structures. If you are a fan of AMC's The Walking Dead you Will without a doubt love this game. From a parental view I would rate this game for 14+. It's very bloody and gory and uses many curse words but it's stuff they hear at school.

Blood and gore 10/10
Story 7/10
Base building 10/10
Searching and scavenging 10/10
Missions 8/10 not including morale missions
Graphics 5/10 Definitly not its strong point
Optimization 3/10 Lots of frame rate issues

Overall it's a solid 8/10 must have

I plan on putting many more hours in this game"

reviewText:
Let me just say after probably 70 hours of offline time painfully watching my allies die from both storyline and sheer acts of stupidy even a glitch where Sam kept running past the base I most dearly love to the  neighbor base that forced me to kill her with zombies cause I couldn't save otherwise. This game had pros and cons. I apoligize for any grammar mistakes.

Otherwise to its a 4/5

Pros
- Great Storyline / Drama / Action for a RPG
- Great selection of weapons
- Painfully realistic but not so much you kill yourself on accident
- Great selection of zombies for a balaced diet of hardcore and easy
- Fast paced but dangerous
- Balanced and Diverse sets of charcters you find that can progress to be more effective
- All characters talk as if they where the main character when you control them.
- Lovable option to press Alt and summon forth your powers on zombies
- Lovable ways to travel in style

Cons
- Tideous as in excessive moments where your base is low on supplies and they can barally find it themselves even if its next door literally
- Not enough choices in conversations to feel you can make a real impact on their opinions
- They are amazing at combat except they do not understand how to equipment themselves aside from excessive snacks and painkillers. ( For insatnce we have a almost 50 guns and some don't even have a pistol in my base. )
- They do not search enough for supplies to live on their own nor do they leave base in groups
- You can't kill people who kill other people
- There are little to zero moments where you just run into survivors or they come and find you
- Zombies are literally endless in a shut off area for some annoying reason
- You can get a whole pick up truck and a maximum allied group but you cannot order any of them help you carry items into the base or from an area. Additionally, you cannot take whats clearly infront of you or search it but instead have to wait 10 or 3 seconds to load a random group of items from some random lit up box and only carry enough to still be able to fight where optionally you can dump it or put it in a vehicle that looks huge but has as much space as a squarilles cheek.
- There is no armor
- There is no customization other than selecting upgrades for your base that leave a lot of open room where you would assume would let you put an extra upgrade but cannot

reviewText:
I know there are a lot of bad reviews about this game but honestly most of these im guessing are problems with their computer not the game because i run this game on high graphics and I get no problems whatsoever. Sure the companions in this game are not the most useful but they do help. One companion could be the diffirence between you getting a lot of resources and a zombie ripping your face off. Vehicles are super useful especially since 1. they can kill zombies really easily, 2. they can carry supplies in the trunk, and 3. there are a lot of them. Also i'll tell you right off the bat that this is a year edition". Year editions like for example "game of the year editions" aren't remastered versions. Year editions are just the original game but with a little bit better graphics and all the DLC but at a lower price. Your not going to get incredibly better graphics with this edition just a little bit better. If your looking for a single-player version of games like Day-Z or H1Z1 then this game is for you. So to sum it all up.

1. not many problems.
2. companions are useful.
3. vehicles are super useful.
4. a little bit better graphics.
5. all DLC.
6. decent combat.
7. pretty good survival aspect.
8. decently interesting story and characters."

reviewText:
I know there are a lot of bad reviews about this game but honestly most of these im guessing are problems with their computer not the game because i run this game on high graphics and I get no problems whatsoever. Sure the companions in this game are not the most useful but they do help. One companion could be the diffirence between you getting a lot of resources and a zombie ripping your face off. Vehicles are super useful especially since 1. they can kill zombies really easily, 2. they can carry supplies in the trunk, and 3. there are a lot of them. Also i'll tell you right off the bat that this is a year edition". Year editions like for example "game of the year editions" aren't remastered versions. Year editions are just the original game but with a little bit better graphics and all the DLC but at a lower price. Your not going to get incredibly better graphics with this edition just a little bit better. If your looking for a single-player version of games like Day-Z or H1Z1 then this game is for you. So to sum it all up.

1. not many problems.
2. companions are useful.
3. vehicles are super useful.
4. a little bit better graphics.
5. all DLC.
6. decent combat.
7. pretty good survival aspect.
8. decently interesting story and characters."

reviewText:
Where to begin?  Lots of negativity in this one but not from me.

Many are pessimistic here because, indeed, this should ave been little more than a patch rather than a total new release.  So, some had to double buy.  However, that stated, this comes with the DLC of Breakdown and Lifeline that the original one had to purchase them seperately.  Here shows, once more, waiting for that right time to buy, instead of getting immediately at release, can be a good thing.  Many games have updates not patched immediately, but held until complete and packaged together wit their expansions then.

One thing, I desperately wish I could use my controller with this one.  Keyboard functions are nominal, but can take that precious second to reach that finger over that would have saved your life by rolling/sprinting away.  I only feel, using a controller I may not have had to restart so many times.  If I had a controller, the way it saves may not be so bad!  Death is perminant for every character, and between that and using the keyboard, completion of the game is possible but improbable.

Visually, the game is stunning, grim, dark, amazing, and terribly terrific.

Audio does cut in and out at times, and is extremely important as your char gives you clues on if you can outpost yet or not a place, and radio from home base updates missions still to do/new on map.  A text caption backup at the bottom of the screen exists, but is far from full proof.

Once I loaded a relatively young game up, at the church, we had our gate per usual but the wall wasn't there.  People were running freely from the church to the parking without using the gate.  Now, this may speed up their little scavinging runs, but what if we had a horde come through just then?

My biggest dislike though is glitching through walls.  It happens pretty frequent, especially when a juggernaut does it when you're trying to pitch him fiery cocktails and not get the NPCs or yourself wasted during a besieged mission.

Tip, at all costs, avoid a jugger when elements would otherwise force you to face it one on one in the open.  Avoid jumping into a horde on the other side of a window to try to kill the juggie at a distance.  Just run away to fight another day.  Strategical retreats, also, are noble.  Especially when twenty something people depend on your continued existence.  You need not tell them you ran away from fighting another thirty zombies, just tell them about the seventy before that you killed over dinner.

You are the apocalypse hero, so tell your story, your way.  History remembers the words of the winner, but dead things tell no tales.  Worry not, for the zombies you ran from will not tattle on you!

Okay, I've mentioned many little nuances, and few large good things.  All those nuances though remove very little from appreciation and immersion for me.  Overall out of a rating of 100, I rate this a 99.  Great product here, UL

reviewText:
Fun game at first, but gets boring and repetitive after a short while. Seems like they had an idea for a game and then took a lot of input from the usual never satisfied gamers, you know the 'wouldn't it be cool if it was co-op?' or ' let us build bases but not have to manage them' or ' I want to play as a (fill in the blank) type person'.
Bottom line it is a third person sandbox zombie survival game. No stratagy needed, no tactics and very lacking in the rpg department. Worth $30? No. Worth $10 sure.
Pros:

Open world
Vehicles
Different styles of guns and melee weapons.

Cons:

Vehicles are to weak. A ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• slimy rotton zombie is not going to total a 1/2 ton military pickup with a reinforced gated bumper. And really all I can put in it is 4 duffle bags of stuff, wish I could have told my Sgt. that in the army...lol. Oh and stop sighns and other little stuff causes severe damage to your vehicle too, and some of the zombies laugh at you cause when you come back, they put all the stuff you tore up your other car on back up.

Combat is very clunky, have a zombie right in front of me, but my toon goes 5 steps away to hit a different one so that one can now get from behind. Partners are a hindrence, best to just leave them behind. They will hold one while your hitting three and get mad when you don't hit the one they are holding.

Video and graphics are typical low budget stuff. A lot of pop ins 20ft away, makes it kinda hard to drive at max speed then suddenly a broken down car pops in or a horde right in front you. Then again, the pop in happens when you're walking and running.....SMH.

Menus are a very bad port job. Sometimes they glitch so bad that keyboard shortcuts are the only way to make them work, mouse is yuky to say the least. No tooltips or very vague, scroll doesn't work well at all.

Tutorial is basicly ' you are a survivor and zombies are everywhere, go make some friends and kill zombies.....end tutorial'

Bottom line, good concept but poorly executed game. DLCs are just more of the same with achievement unlockers (see listening to whining gamer input) and a quick cheap storyline for the military. Game is steril and incomplete, would hate to have seen it before the graphics update. Best thing they could do is open up the sdk and let people mod it into a good game.

reviewText:
If you're into survival in general and Zombies in particular this is a game for you. With three different playstyles; Storydriven (State of Decay), level based (State of Decay: Breakdown) where you can reset the game to reach a higher difficulty in the next level, and last but not least the Military perspective (State of Decay: Lifeline) on a City map specific for that story.

The story told as well as the game in general emphasizes the building of a community of survivors and the teamwork required. Despite it being a Single-Player game only, they succeed quite well in portraying the everyday struggle of a (albeit fictional) Zombie Apocalypse.

However it does get repetitive, the narrative could have been expanded upon. Especially in Breakdown this becomes obvious, but if you aren't annoyed by that one issue you're free to enjoy the game on higher and higher levels of difficulty with each new level you reach. I have noticed some glitches related to the graphics, specifically the lighting and shadows which is unrelated to the game functionality and I do not know if this is a problem on my system only or a general issue with the game. It is only noticeable in the early morning hours of each 24 hr cycle so I think it's a minor issue.

In Lifeline you get all the cool Military Hardware so desired in the other two versions of the game. Based on a story where a team of soldiers find themselves isolated in a City full of Zombies, their only support being Helicopter supply drops hence the name of the title; Lifeline. Once the storyline is completed you are given the option to continue playing and save as many civilians that you can find (still alive) or end the story and the game to finalize your score.

Overall a very enjoyable game. It's a shame there is no Multiplayer mode, though.

It's no flawless diamond, but it's FUN.\n\nDon't let the Mixed" rating fool you. If you look up the original State of Decay (that's not longer available for purchase)
date: you'll see it had plenty of people praising it. Most of the negative reviews for SoD seem to be original owners who were upset they bought the special edition and found it didn't offer much more than the original.\n\nThe difficulty is sneaky
recommended: and I mean that in a good way
hoursPlayed: like when you try to sneak up on a lone zombie
voteText: only to realize (too late!) that there was a cluster of zombies standing just out of sight
helpfulPercent: or when you leap out of a window to make a quick get away
votesHelpful: only to land right in the path of a zombie horde. The tension can ramp up quick
votesTotal: and a moment of carelessness can result in a deadly chase.\n\nHouses that aren't cleared every so often can get infested
votesFunny: leading to more freaks (special infected) and hordes wandering around (and even wind up attacking your home base). To compensate
commentsCount: you can build outposts
column16: set traps and recruit more survivors to defend your home. It's a fun feature and it's nice to know you can create small pockets of (relative) safety.\n\nMy rig isn't high end by any means (Laptop
column17: 5th Gen. Intel Core i3
column18: integrated HD graphics)
column19: so I have to run it on minimum graphics
column20: but it rarely chugs. Occasionally
column21: a zombie will be standing in a wall
column22: or I'll swing endless at a zombie and the hits won't register until I dodge away (not sure if that's a graphic problem on my end or a bug). That's about the worst problem I've encountered in my 20 hours of gameplay.\n\nGive it a chance

reviewText:
I met one or two people who worked on the art of this game and kept meaning to get around to trying it so I really, _really_ wanted to like it, and may try more to check the DLC content or out of masochism, but seriously the base game is unbelievably annoying due to various bugs, trash filler content, BS design decisions, and complete unfriendliness to just trying the game out and exploring.  It doesn't look bad for a lower budget game so I guess the art people did do their part, but the rest of this game has too much downside.  I can't believe are still like this almost 3 years after release.

TL;DR = don't buy this game but I found it so annoying after while I am dropping a text wall here.

Here is a *not even complete* list of annoying crap from the base game:

Dumb friendly AI:
- Ally NPCs can provide backup, unless they randomly decide to leave you.  They also tend to leave at the start of difficult fights and mission sections with no warning or easy rule for all circumstances.
- Ally NPCs are often dumb as stones.  Sometimes during fights/sieges you have to put yourself at high risk because they are so stupid the will do nothing but continuously board up a window/etc.

Engine/physics problems:
- Characters glitch into geometry.  Zombies glitch in geometry.  Occasionally this will screw you and/or a mission hard.
- Climbing and jumping mechanics are sometimes crap.  Characters can get stuck on seemingly trivial objects/inclines, and can climb up certain objects which for some reason they cant climb down without taking damage (ladders work, but things like rocks do not).  Also when trying to jump down some areas you will slide" in the air causing a farther fall and damage.  Sometimes will  also slide/fall off platforms when there is no reason
date:
or fail to attach to a ladder when climbing down from something.
- Cars sometimes flip from almost nothing.  Once I flipped by turning ~10 degrees not even going fast.  Another time I bumped into a zombie going ~5mph in a parking lot.

Garbage design choices:
*** No way manually save/reload.  This is ridiculous in general and total garbage when trying to learn.  Something really bad happen?  Made any mistake?  Now choose between the hours or days to redo everything or carry on screwed over often due to some game glitch (loved losing the main character almost fully leveled because a horde is glitching stuck on a cliff next to a feral I can't stealth past and oh look my dumbass NPC ally left me on a mission suddenly 10x harder than any surrounding content). Why not have a noob mode/story mode and a hardcore mode (and for such a trivial developer task...)?  "Authenticity" can go to hell (and there are already so many super-unrealistic aspects of this game). I'd prefer the thing called ‚Äúfun.‚Äù  This single feature would lessen or negate all other bugs and aggravations but obviously some designer thought they knew better and wasting your time was OK with them.  Unbelievably stupid and worse than anything on this list my a mile.
- No ‚Äúpause‚Äù feature while trying to read UI options or journal entries.
- No way to turn off AFK progression.  This is especially annoying if you are essentially forced to AFK/quit for a while to rest characters.  It is also just incredibly annoying in general.  Oh look bad things happened when you went to work or tried to have a life.
- Very little explanation of what to do in the game past the most basic mechanics.  You learn mainly by trial and error and being forced to read online resources.  See also: no save/load errors--> massive waste of time to restart.

Time wasting filler design:
- The most interesting missions are probably story lines
recommended: at least to a newer player.  Except they are hard to get to because 99% of your time ends up devoted to the massive spamming of mundane threats and trash missions for lost/angry/depressed/sick/whatever NPCs so you will waste hours running the same crap over and over until you have a window.  Or you can just do them and risk ???/deaths by ignoring other tasks.  None of them show at all how important they are
voteText: what consequences might be
helpfulPercent: if they are main missions or optional (though the standard spam ones become more obvious after a wile)
votesHelpful: etc. etc. etc..\n- Zombies sometimes regenerate stupidly fast even in non-infested  areas/houses sometimes making gameplay super tedious.  Have had missions next to random houses before where new crops spawn every 2 minutes forcing you to fight endless trash mobs and making near zero progress.\n- You take forever just to search a shelf
votesTotal: or can do it faster at risk of opening a black hole out of which zombies pour.  It's super fun searching slowly after hundreds of times.\n- Even the healthy characters have some of the worst run/jog endurance ever making travel on foot super slow and annoying.\n- You can carry several large objects/weapons
votesFunny:
but 3 twinkies or bottles of aspiring apparently take up the same space.
- Searched objects don't retain highlighting so if you leave anything behind ever and want it later you have to manually hunt and peck to find storage.


UI:
- Controls don't handle very well and mouse aim works different than most action games which is annoying (affects move direction but not attack direction).  Attempts to aim in crowded melee combat are garbage.
- Hard to find relevant notices/mission text in journal list of everything from gain +1 to X skill or ‚Äúbob took a dump +5 influence‚Äù and ‚Äúbob accidentally shot bill in the face for no reason for the second time today -1 influence.‚Äù  Plus the game basically penalizes you for any trying to read these thoroughly (see: no pausing).
- Cant change profile names.  So the more you lose for stupid reasons and try to restart the more confusing which horked saved game is which
- Home management UI is sometimes clunky/unclear especially mouse-over text


So many cool ideas here executed poorly or 3/4 done.  Waste of decent visuals/sound on at best mediocre quickly repetitive gameplay and at worst infuriatingly awful rubbish that makes you pay for any mistake (or sometimes its own glitches) to the extreme and won't even stop taking a crap on your head when you turn it off.  Game had minor interesting moments but overall has been MUCH MORE ANNOYING THAN FUN = DOWNVOTE."

reviewText:
Zombie survival game with more focus on sneaking round the zombies to gather supplies than just button mashing head smashing. Gather survivors and supplies while staying hidden from zombies.

Overall 7.5/10

Pros
Base building and customization is good, improvements take real time and survivors use up supplies therefore realism
Sneaking mechanics are solid
Fighting zombies feels as hard as it would in reality
Decent sized map with fair degree of variability
Good sound mechanics mean zombies can hear you from outside the house you're searching or can hear you breaking into places
Freedom to choose your own home base site was nice

Cons
The campaign is quite short and ends very abruptly. Only really 5ish hours of work if you focused entirely on it
Quite glitchy with zombies often teleporting through walls and doors

reviewText:
State of decay does not have the worlds best graphics but it compensates (I think) in gameplay and challange. This game is not flawless (no game is) ocassional glitches are annoying but not a deal breaker, zombie hords are constant and never ending.  Anyone in this game can die, and I mean ANYONE! my biggest pet peeve is when the zeds swarm you and you have no way to stop a character from dying.  Zombies (zeds) are way too awair of their surroundings making stealth a moot point accept in the very beginning.

The story is not very compelling but still enjoyable.

Guns are helpful but tend to lead to  more zeds coming to attack you, melee is dangerous and comes with it's own shortcomings.  This game is not for the ill-tempered or easily annoyed because you will have both happen to you.

Stealth needed to be better, more options for building forts all would have added to the enjoyment of this game.

You end the game walk away only to come back and discover that all your safehouses have been overrun, Half the people you rescued are dead, (for no reason) and in general moral sucks. Yet when you left the game everying was on a highnote, so not having everything you have worked hard to achive suddenly fall apart while you were not playing the game would definatly been better, no would make more sense.

Despite all this I have still enjoyed this game and would reccomend it with a warning, its your fault if you put you fist through your monitor.

reviewText:
Having played this for as long as I have, I have just a few comments:

-it doesn't have wonderful graphics

-it has no happy endings

-you can't kill other players (read what you buy before you buy it)

-you have to save NPCs

-you have to earn acheives by actually doing them, not by cheesing them somehow

-you have to create and maintain viable communities.

It has great replay value, you get to kill lotsa zombies, and if you have a moderately decent PC, knowledge of keyboard commands in Windows, you can easily have a fun gaming experience saving NPCs at the same time. If your defintiion of a good time is looking for humans to kill, you're going to have a hard time here...altho it is possible. :)

reviewText: I feel people are being totally unfair to this release. This is one of my favorite games of all time and this version adds a lot, great new characters, new weapons, new missions, a variety of much needed new vehicle skins, new animations, along with better graphics and slightly better performance. People think because they bought the original version they are entitled to the remaster, but that's not usually how things work. I had no problem buying this game twice. This game is worth every penny. I've got way more out of it than most $60 AAA titles, so even buying both versions of the game and all the DLC I feel I'v well gotten my money's worth. Plus I love to support the developers of this great game. If you already have State of Decay, and don't think it's worth it to buy it again, than don't buy it. The original version is still great. If you absolutely love SoD and can't get enough, than $30  I keep both installed and mod the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of the original version.\n\nFor me State of Decay YOSE is tied with Telltale's Walking Dead for the greatest zombie game of all time. It makes me sad this has mixed" reviews becuase some people felt entitled to a free copy."

reviewText:
For a first timer of State of Decay, I was absolutely blown away by how much fun this game is, particularly with the Breakdown mode - technically it is a DLC package, but its a mode of its own that is now the prime source of all of my play time.

State of Decay is sort of a family friendly- no, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that; nothing family friendly about zombies. It's the other side of the zombie game coin; as opposed to FPTS (First Person Trolling Shooter) LagZ, this game focuses on the community side of the zombie apocalypse. This game is essentially Post-Apoc Tycoon, for how you have to meet the needs of your human assets while pushing off the needs of the undead trying to destroy your brothers and sisters.

On a laptop, this thing runs fairly well; it doesn't freeze up or get the blue crashing" wheel that we all know and loathe; it is particularly frustrating playing this thing on a laptop
recommended: for those of you on gaming laptops. It's possible and more than capable
hoursPlayed: but it isn't advisable\n\nFor a game spawned from the Xbox LIVE Arcade Store
voteText: this one emerged the untamable king
helpfulPercent: and spread its empire onto Steam. My heart goes out to those who feel scammed by repurchasing this or whatever

reviewText:
Do not understand how this review got marked a few times for not being helpful? Oh well..

State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition despite the negativity for this game due to previous owners concerns, it is a great game to play. Purchased the game while on sale and was not disappointed at all with the overall gameplay. While playing the run-through of State of Decay Year-One, it was rather challenging but yet balanced to keep up the stamina of the characters.  The Breakdown edition is very balanced as you get to higher levels. The Lifeline edition is a great story line to follow to the end twice since you need to in order to get both achievements.

With the Breakdown and Lifeline DLC with State of Decay Year-One edition is great package.

My personal complaints are:
Lily broadcasts seems to pester a little too much at times about other tasks when you wish to secure your home site stockpiles. The way I managed to search all the buildings and it helped to level up the characters Maya and Marcus with less difficulties, is to perform those searches before entering the church at the start. After sufficiently searched and found the needed stocks, only then enter the church to continue on with the storyline.

The characters and zombies can walk on water and do not swim.
My personal suggestions are:
The pick-up trucks and SUVs should have more available room then 6 slots since they do have more space in reality to toss the duffle bags inside. Something like 10 would be reasonable.

It would have been awesome to have multiplayer sessions of the game. To have a real community together to secure resources and defenses for the home site.

Would like to have seen a home site big enough to implement all the facilities that you can add for the site. It could have had a home site requirement of 20 survivors needed and 75 building materials.

Having 8 outposts is sufficient but it would have been even better if they were setup as mini-sites that you could lock in survivors into position on the roof to snipe oncoming zombies and you must maintain their stock levels in order to keep up the defenses and not just placing the standard mines for the surrounding area.

Even though the game map is big; it just still seems rather small after playing for a while. Having a bigger map area would have been awesome.

As mentioned in complaints above but now noted as a suggestion here, the swimming ability. If you were to swim in the polluted waters (filled with dead zombies) you could get sick compared to swimming in clear waters.
I could continue to add to the list but it is still a great game to play. I do hope that the developers ‚ÄúUndead Labs‚Äù will continue with this game and create a great series/add-ons with it with all the suggestions made from so many players listed here and their forums.

Also, thank you to so many players on Steam that created great guides to obtain the achievements, it helped a whole lot.

reviewText:
I turned this game on, not knowing what to expect other than zombies. I've only been playing for a little while but I'm hooked. This game is what any game based on AMC's The Walking Dead should have been. The price was right and I love me some zombies. I understand there was a version before this one, I didn't play that version.

some good stuff

+great mechanics for food, ammo, and medicine caches
+satisfying to knee zombies in the head or finish them on the ground
+immersive world that changes even when you turn the game off
+short, tense dialog, which fits the setting,
+cheeseball humor is appropriately few and far between
+cars handle differently and driving & mobile combat is fun

obviously the game is not without complications
-engine endures frequent fps drops
-missions can get repetitive
-slightly steep learning curve (early on I lost a few characters I liked due to ignorance)
-lots of notifications in the journal which feel overwhelming

worth my money.

reviewText:
Played an extra 121 hours on the previous version of SoD and owned all DLC before buying this one. Game was too awesome to wait.

New to the game: Ignore negative reviews on this page (the previous same game was 88% positive), and get it. Game is awesome. Best zombie game EVER. Breakdown is awesome! Lifeline too.

New to the game (and its on sale): Buy it! Awesome game!! Open-World-Zombies-Survival-Community with special-zombies! Died? Meh - take over a community member! Breakdown DLC is cool.

Owned original game: Quit your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing and buy it when it goes on sale. I gladly payed 50% off to get the few extra features than the original game, because this game was so awesome.

My only regret about this game is that it isn't multiplayer. Single player still is cool though, so its a meh gripe.

You can run over zombie hordes! and then back up to knock down the ones you missed! I must admit its satisfying to swerve to just miss a power pole, to dislodge that zombie after your brains (before your driver door is ripped off and you ripped from the car)! :D

Will return after playing Fallout 4 - waited a LONG time for that one... (pity the sale and FO4 was so close in time... sigh)

reviewText:
For all of you looking for a true zombie survival game, you've come to the right place. You're going to spend a ridiculous amount of time having stories to share with your friends unfold before your eyes.

The base game has an enjoyable story, though it's the sandboxy feel that goes along with it that makes this game an excellent one. You are continually capable of working toward your next story goal at your own pace, though if you're like me you'll find the majority of the game is spent exploring, collecting supplies, building up your base, dealing with other survivor groups, gaining skills for you survivors, etc. Every character has a unique backstory and there are -a lot- of survivors out there that you might run into and have join you.

The base building is simple, yet very enjoyable as well. Depending on what skills your survivors have, different options are available and you have plenty of options available to you. Do you want to be able to support more survivors? Build a bunkhouse and a garden so that they have a comfortable place to sleep and food to eat if your scavenged supplies run low. Looking to cut back on the sneaking around and really take the fight to the zombies? An infirmary will keep your survivors healthy and a munitions shop will keep them well armed. Just remember, even healthy, well armed survivors might run into a challenge when facing off against the 'freaks' or special zombies.

The Breakdown DLC removes the deep story aspect of the the vanilla campaign, though it adds a brand new achievement system that unlocks 'hero' survivors that, more often than not, are more capable than your average survivor. This mode also has 'Breakdown Levels', each time you complete one you move on to the next, more challenging phase, with new survivor achievements to unlock.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the zombie survival genre. I'd been looking for a game like this for a very long time and was extremely happy when I installed it and truly learned what it was all about. Enjoy and I'd love to hear your stories!

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: I played the original State of Decay, on PC, and loved it despite all its flaws.

So what about SoD:YOSE? Well, it's more of the same minus the most obvious flaws, that's mainly  the weirdly behaved renderer, which seemed to render at 720p internally, then upsampled everything to whatever resolution you had chosen, doing so without any sort of filtering. So it looks a lot better now. Still no antialiasing option in the game's menus, but you can always force that from your video-card control panel.
The engine still isn't very good at streaming the world geometry in a fluid fashion, so the fps still drops significantly at times, slowing the gameplay down A LOT in the process, but that usually doesn't last for more than a second. Might also be a lot less noticeable on a SSD, I'll have to give that a try...
Lastly, the quests' progression will still get stuck when some random zombies forget to get into the quest area and you'll still have to either chase them down or wait for them to despawn in order for the mission continue.

In conclusion, I'd say it's not exactly the facelift I was hoping for. The graphics still look sort of dated, the engine still can't handle the size of the map (I could fit the game 8 times in RAM, but the engine insists on swapping and streaming from the HDD like it's 2008), the zombie AI still gets in the way... But you know what? It's still a great survival/resource management game, probably the best in the zombie flavor: numerous quests, some generic, some unique; nice story; great character management/progression system. Plus you get all the DLCs, which are pretty good. I'd say you get a lot of game for your money... even if some small part of me still wishes it would have been released as a free update for those who already had it, because if you only sort of liked the first iteration, I'm not sure what little changed can justify buying the game a second time. Me, I had a great time with it, and I'm having an even better time with this one.

TLDR: Is it worth a buy? If you like the zombie survival genre and didn't get the original game, yes. Definitely. If you already have State of Decay, you may give it a pass, unless you really liked the game or you feel the horrible upscaling-with-worst-possible-filtering engine prevented you from truely enjoying it.

reviewText: You will play multiple characters, one at a time. Straight up zombie killing fiesta and the occasional missions/side missions to keep the game going for a bit. I truly hate the constantly distressed housemates that you need to help in order to regulate the overall happiness of your base. AIs can't drive so they will walk all the way to the loot locations (guess what happens to and fro?!). There is definitely no break in between tasks for you to discover other things (that don't exist anyway). Other than killing zombies, limited upgrades on your home base and weapons, the game does not go beyond that. If you want a beautiful game and weapon varieties, you should play it!

reviewText:
This is a really great survival/management/exploration zombie game.  It's -almost- the perfect combination of different genres.  It only falls a little flat on the looseness of it's excecution.

A really terrible quest log makes your goals confusing, with missions and morale issues popping up and disappearing quickly while you struggle to figure out where you're even supposed to be headed.

If the combat controls were a little tighter, and the management tools were more powerful, this would be a perfect zombie survival game.  Why not emulate Assassin's Creed for fighting and exploration?  And your fellow survivors are almost useless because they will only scavenge buildings when you are already there - Why can't I tell someone to take 3 people and go grab the medicine we spotted in the pharmacy last week?  What about a contruction tree, rather than vague descriptions and no hint at what you are building up to?

Hopefully there will be a State of Decay 2, and it will combine aspects of tighter, more specialized games into a really fun symphony of death and destruction.  8/10 would send Alan to his death again.

reviewText:
I'd like to start out by saying that I haven't played the original SoD game, so this was my first foray in this experience. As far as a survival simulator goes this game is so much fun. Running a group of survivors brings a lot of challenges. I find it so gratifying allocating time and effort towards different tasks such as different missions, supplies and home dillemas. The game provides enough variety in it's gameplay to keep you interested for quite a while.

It isn't all rainbows unfortunetly. For one it's a fairly low effort PC port. I'd like to see some more effort towards optimization. Traveling at high speeds in a car can (well always) provides some substantial frame rate drops. When the frame rate does stay constant you have some glaring texture pop-in to enjoy on your trip. Draw distance in this game is extremely disappointing. I'd like to see the developers use the extra PC horsepower to their benefit. Unfortunetly they've skipped that part.

I would recommend this game to new commers of the game if you're looking for a zombie survival type experience. State of Decay really nails the survival parts of it. It provides plently of hours of fun despite the graphical impetence in some regards.

reviewText:
I guess you could call me one of the 'lucky ones' as I bought the game after Undead Labs decided to rework it all and charge the people who had already bought the game once more, to be able to play the then 'new' update.

The game itself is amazingly set, it suits the whole apocalypse look throughout the game very well, and It's a joy to just look at, even though the game now is somewhat 'old'. I've always wanted a zombie survival singleplayer game set just like State of Decay is, and it has everything you could possibly want.

It's a game you could easily sit and play for hours on end, it's somewhat addicting and it always has things such as side missions that wants you to not stop playing.

I'd say it's a 'slow pace' survival game, you chose your own path to some extent, a large extent that is, which I think is a very important plus. Overall great game, great looking game.

reviewText:
With all the negative reviews, I feel I have to do this release some justice.

I have spent 110 hours on the original and 35 hours on this remastered version already.

For newcomers, State of Decay is an innovative zombie survival with an open-world GTA"-esque vibe to it.

There is no other game on the market that fills the gap like this and considering the huge modding community for State of Decay
date:
I strongly believe that this is a "love it or hate it" game. I cannot stop playing Breakdown.

The definitive version looks stunning remastered in 1080p with new objectives and game mechanics. You can also import your original save files.

As for bugs
recommended: there are a few minor which are common to the open-world genre
hoursPlayed: but there has not been one instance where my gameplay or immersion have been interrupted and there are certainly no new bugs with this release.\n\nHaving said all that
voteText: for those who did not enjoy the original State of Decay
helpfulPercent:
this release will not change your mind.

I advise prospective buyers to read up on the new features and watch some gameplay before deciding whether to purchase.

Do not be too easily put off by the negative reviewers who were disappointed after asking Santa Claus for too many presents.

Sincerely

reviewText:
I'll start off by saying that I got the YOSE edition during the steam summer sale and it was worth every ~$8 that I spent on it. At this point I have 38 hours into it after beating the storyline, I haven't even touched the DLC yet. The best thing about this game is the gameplay, I would compare it to Left for dead with a little bit of GTA mixed in. I'll make list of my pros and cons so you don't have to read a wall of text.

Pros;

Very enjoyable combat
BASE BUILDING with some tower defense mixed in
Decent ammount of weapons
special combat/finishing moves that are learned over time
handful of drivable vehicles
varied missions
large selection of playable characters
varied and unique attributes and quirks for the characters
a few unique zombie types
Cons; I'll write a bit more on the cons after

ported from console came
the game engine does not scale well
quirkly environment
stupid AI
actually looks a lot like L4D2 (could be a pro or con)
a few bugs
no minimap interaction
draw distance waaaaay to short
traveling becomes a bit of a chore, a fast travel system of some sort would have been nice
inventory management is also a pain
vehicles don't feel quite right
menus and team/base interaction is bad
zero character management if your not playing them
I think a lot of the cons boil down to the fact that the game is a console port. I have a beefy gaming PC with a brand new Nvidia 970, 8Gb of ram, and an i5 @3.2 which can run most games at 60fps on the highest settings. That said I had a lot of issues of texture and environment pop in, really poor draw distance, and just overall very poorly optimized for PC. In fact I turned on Fraps to check my frames per second to find out that if Vsync is enabled it locks the fps at 30. The biggest problem that I had was when driving, when moving at a higher speed the draw distance issue was really obvious and the game itself would lag witch made it even harder to drive giving the amount of invulnerable objects that there are to dodge.

The other big issue that I started to notice after playing for a few dozen hours was how bad the menu and management system is. There is absolutely zero character management if you are not playing a given character. In a game about survival and asset management that seems like a big oversight and missed opportunity. I imagine it was partially planned that way since many of the missions revolve around helping out or rescuing the other survivors that have left the base but it would have been was more fun to designate certain characters for scavageing roles or to be able to lock more important characters to the base. Special characters actually fill roles in the base and give your base bonuses if they are manageing the kitchen, farm, etc so it sucks to have them go out. I think I logged in one day to find all my neighboring survivors had died while I was out which kind of sucked. But realisticly in my playthrough I think I only noticed one of my survivors dieing and that was because we were on a mission together and he was torn in half by a tank mob.

The last think I would mention is that there really isn't a lot of explination for the dynamics of the game. There are a lot of things happening on the map at a given time and the dispatch character will constantly be reminding you that your running out of time to take care of certain things but for the life of me I couldn't tell what the consequences of my action or inaction were.

Anyway, the cons seem big but the gameplay is fun enough that you should be able to make it through the campaign without too much work. Also there are some fixes out there for for some of the problems that I pointed out, if you tweak any of your PC games then you should be able to find them. I would highly recommend picking this game up if its on sale and it is probably still worth it at full price. It certanly scratched that Left for Dead itch that I didn't know that I had.

p.s. - If they skinned this game with The Walking Dead and fixed some of my cons it would be the ultimate zombie game.

reviewText:
What can I say about this that has not already been said? Probably nothing, but as this was one of the games that got me back into gaming after a long hiatus I have to say something.

In a gaming market saturated with zombie survival games what interested me about State of Decay was the clear George A. Romero inspiration.

The zombies are classic Romero, a slow ponderous mass of dead flesh that are all kinds of messed up, and as such they often lull the player into a false sense of security with their weak, slow movements. This is their weakness but collectively this is also their strength.

It is easy to forget than more than a handful of these creatures are much than a match for the average player and often while allowing yourself to get carried away it is easy to overstep and find yourself face to face with a zombie horde. The results of this are obvious and as you struggle fruitlessly for what seems like hours the end is inevitable.

And it is an end.

Once a character dies they are gone for good and if you have not succeeded in bringing in new survivors the longevity of your community is in real question. This fact, coupled with the need to find recourses and protect your borders, can easily overwhelm even a well organised player; leading to ultimate destruction.

There‚Äôs a lot good about this game, but I am sad to say it also has a few negatives that grate on the player the longer they play.

Characters are almost non existent, use of dialogue is simplistic and does not allow for much variety and the result of this is that missions can become formulaic and lack interest. This is not as bad as it seems, as the open world provides a great deal of interest in itself; but greater character development would have improved my personal enjoyment a vast amount.

The worst thing about this game must be the pure stupidity of many of the character, partly this is due to the afore mentioned lack of variety but its also because the random nature of the story means that often characters take up residence in the most foolish of places.

This means that the player is sometimes frustrated by the need to protect characters who are simply too dumb to care about. On occasion prompting this particular player to wish I could put them out of their misery (or at least mine).

All this having been said, I enjoyed this game a great deal; in spite of some poor storytelling the game mechanics worked well to instil alternating moments of the habitually mundane and the fight-for-your-life terror that makes the game rather unusual. As in the Romero movies that I feel inspired the game, State of Decay is less about the living dead and more about how we react to them, the terror is not about death but about how we live.

I, for one, am hoping that the poor storytelling and awful characterisations will either be fixed at some point with future updates or will disappear in a continuation of the game franchise.

reviewText: This game rules. I can understand the negative reviews if you owned the first one. As they say they have the same thing, but for people like myself who never tried it till now, this game is great, runing over zombies and bodies and blood everywhere as bodies fling 50 feet in the air. reviewText:
The story is a little under developed. You're pretty often running alone in sandbox or otherwise which is just unrealistic.

The map is really bare and pretty small. It gets repetitive quickly.

Game looks fine and plays well. I really enjoyed most of the mechanics. Character progression could be a more in depth.

There is an influence systems which determines whether or not you can do anything outside of looting and killing zombies. This is a really LAME system. When you do convince someone to come with you it only temporary and they leave you if you start a mission.

Overall the game is fine and youll enjoy a single play through perhaps more if you have the time to waste. There is a great idea hidden here in poor execution but any zombie game where it feels like you're alone doing everything is not okay. Give me more character development, more despair, more freedoms and a bigger map, and for god sake if you're going to give me a group of survivors to work with don't make them so freaking useless.

Basically take the freedom and level of immersion of a game like Project Zomboid offers smash it into this game and removed a few quirky mechanics (such as influence) and you've got yourself a winner. As it is, this game has a great idea but they just didn't deliver.

State of Decay
Project Zomboid
DayZ

Combined these three games with an intelligent AI system so it seems like youre living in the zombies world then you've won it. You don't really need a storyline, but give me the freedom to create my own with.

This game SCREAMS for a coop or multiplayer mode. It really feels empty most of the time.

When it comes down to it, the storyline isnt horrible and you'll get your moneys worth if you like GTA sytle games + zombies. The breakdown DLC is neat but really sort of time consuming and repetitive, the lifeline dlc is meh.

reviewText: First, I want to say that I am NOT a returning player. I never played the original State of Decay, so this game is all new to me and I am loving it. I did run into one bug while playing the game, I kept crashing when trying to run one particular mission, but I ended up going back later in the game and finishing that line just fine. I bought the Breakdown DLC along with the game and I have to say, this DLC is what really makes the game worth playing. The stand alone game is really just a warm up to the challenges you face as you level through Breakdown. The stand alone game was good, just not challenging enough, so I really recommend learning the game there and then continuing through Breakdown. I have yet to try the Lifeline DLC, although it looks to be an interesting change to the story as well.

reviewText:
I've read some of the reviews on here, and quite frankly, they are baffling to me.  This isn't a sequel.  This isn't much more than a GOTY version, in fact.

The graphics are noticeably better than the original version of this game.  The gameplay seems a bit better (game is a little harder than I remember, but that could be my own perception being off).

That all said, I had the first version, but had never purchased the DLC for it.  If you already had all of the DLC, this purchase might be hard to justify at full price.  For me, not having played any of the DLC, along with the minor improvements made, this was a solid purchase.

reviewText:
First off, I ask that anyone who agrees with my review or likes it, please up vote it to help combat the people who're posting negative reviews and downvoting positive reviews to give the game a bad reputation for reasons that have nothing to do with Gameplay.

If you enjoy Zombie Survival Immersion, State of Decay is the game for you.
State of Decay is a Zombie Survival game that focuses on community building and management rather than pure Zombie Apocalypse Horror. You will have a group of survivors and a Home that you must defend and manage. You have to scavenge for resources such as Food, Medicine, Ammo Caches, Construction Materials, and Fuel. But you have to decide, am I going to be quiet and take my time searching
date: or am I going to search really quickly and risk alerting every Zombie in the area that I'm in this house!"
hoursPlayed: this can lead to many quick and painful deaths
voteText: which is only amplified by the fact that this game uses a perma-death system. If you die
helpfulPercent: then that survivor is dead
votesHelpful: they aren't coming back. If you have more survivors back at home
votesTotal: then you can continue playing as one of them
votesFunny:
but you won't be bringing back that dead survivor in any way.
State of Decay is much more of a casual game that you can sit back and enjoy your Zombie Apocalypse with a few heart pumping moments like when you run out of stamina in the middle of a fight you can't run from.

I personally enjoy this game because it has a higher level of immersion than most Zombie Survival games these days. The fact that it is free-roam while maintaining a linear progression so as to keep you moving
commentsCount: only adds to my enjoyment.\nThe survivors have their own quirky little comments that can give you a giggle or even a facepalm moment for how much a survivors comment can annoy the hell out of you. It brings to life the fact that each survivor really has their own personality and brings something new to the community.\nBeware
column16: vehicles can and WILL be damaged to the point of explosion. And if that happens
column17: RUN FOREST
column18: RUN! Because that particular big bang
column19: will bring the hordes running for a free happy meal.\n\nIn the main campaign
column20: you start off up north in the woods
column21: I like to call it Camping Central or Ranger Town. You're rather clueless as to what's happening because you've been outside of news broadcasts and such while out camping. You then proceed to the Ranger Station and things start to become clearer as you go
column22: you will meet new people
column23: and have to decide how to work with them. I'm trying to avoid too much info to avoid spoilers. After you get through the basic intro
column24: you will be at a church with your group of survivors. You must protect them
column25: the church and scavenge for supplies. After some time
column26: it becomes your responsibility to move to a safer location
column28: leave the town to complete the campaign.\n\nIn the Breakdown DLC
column29: you're in the same town/map as in the main campaign. Only with a bit more freedom as the main campaign missions have been removed. You start in the middle of nowhere and get given the choice on how to proceed
column30: you can start a new community as a single survivor
column31: or you can join one of three communities that are available from the get go. Items no longer respawn in buildings once you've scavenged them (not like they do in the main campaign). And this time when you leave town
column33: so be prepared for it. Because each level of Breakdown
column34: while there's a better chance for better loot
column35: will also increase the spawn rate of Zombies and Special Zombies. Making it harder as you go along. Giving you more replayability to scratch your Zombie Survival Simulator itch.\n\nIn Lifeline
column36: you take on the role of a group of soldiers that are trying to recover a means to combat the virus (very Resident Evil like if you ask me). You will be on a new map made up mostly of highways to get you around the map faster due to the lengthy distance for each objective. This DLC is rather fun to play once you've put a bit of time into the main Campaign and Breakdown DLC
column37: it gives you some variety and new storyline and characters to follow.\n\nEach character in this game has their own personality

this has only been improved upon with the Year One Survival Edition.
What YOSE has brought to the table is some old bug fixes for this GOTY-like release plus many other improvements such as:

This is not to mention the higher resolution availability for YOSE compared to the Original SoD.

But the bottom line is
