reviewText: This is the zombie game that I've been waiting a long time for! There are some minor bugs and the graphics aren't the best but overall it's a great experience. The zombie apocalypse is overwhelming at times, which is part of the fun and it has some elements of an RPG, which I think is awesome. Deaths are always a tragedy since characters can be extremely valuable to your survival depending on how you upgrade them and building a base that can defend against the zombies is another fun task. If you haven't tried this game, check out some videos and I'm sure they will raise your interest. No regrets on my part.

reviewText:
Bad reviews are about the devs republishing an upgraded version of the game. Don't see the issue really. This game clearly still has the same bugs since I've encounterd them. And they got the old version which I had rather had, since this one takes a lot more from my computer's performance so I do have lag at times. But really, it's not like Square Enix is gonna give me the Final Fantasy VII remake for free either cause I bought the original FFVII back then. Guess people always gotta Q.Q about something.

Anyway, the bad reviews have nothing to do with the gameplay itself. The game itself is great. After playing through both Walking Dead games from Telltale, I was looking for something similar. Not just a brainless zombie shooting FPS game. Something with a story to it. This game, has that. I can definitely see it take place in the same universe as The Walking Dead, which to me is great.

You also have to make choices in this game that could lead to good or bad things, find other survivors, team up, people will die, you may have to relocate again, etc.etc. I haven't gotten too far in the game yet, but so far I am really enjoying it. If you like zombie survivals games with a story to it, or The Walking Dead games from Telltale then I think this one's right up your alley!

reviewText: I once had the original version of State of Decay, and its been a while since ive played it again. I really like this game just like the first time i played it, i love the survival aspect of the apocolops that no other zombie game has, it is not just a hack and slash zombie game, it felt like i was in a season of the walking dead. The crafting and upgrades you can do to your safe house is increadable. this game is the first zombie game that i have played that actually has consecuenses to dying, the zombies actually post a threat and when you come across a horde it is quite challenging and sometimes sadening when your character dies because they dont respawn, you just play as another character. Everything you do in this game has cocequences which can be good or bad. This is the closest to a realistic zombie survival game i have every played. If you like the Walking Dead, then you will fall in love with this game.

reviewText:
So what is this game?

It's a zombie apocalypse open survival game.
Enough said to be honest.

Story: X/10
So why a X instead of a number?
Well, it might be because I really don't know which mission is the story, and there's basically no story at all at the same time where there is one. The game throws a x amount of missions at the player at roughly the same time.

Gameplay: 8/10
The gameplay is good, really good and addictive but it ha it's rough edges.

The game starts with introducing the settlement mechaninc a settlement is a place where the survivors that you found live. For them to be able to live, they need food, medication and a place to sleep. Food and medication is able be found within the world itself, while you need to build a place for your survivors to sleep. Each settlement has it's own selected areas where you can choice what you want to build. If you want to have a survivor with you, well you gonna want to do a lot of side missions so you can rise your morale in your settlement, a low morale will make people leave your settlement.

Looting is a big mechanic in the game, you do it like 80% of the time. It works but it's kinda weird. For some reason rushing a looting process makes more sound than shooting a zombie with a shotgun.

The fighting" mechanic works more or less. Shooting feels good but actually fighting feels awkward most of the time.
You need to earn fame before you can take a weapon from your settlemet
date:
yes you can find a gun and ammo in the world itself.

Music: 7/10
It's nothing special
recommended:
but it's quite impressive when you can hear a gun shot in the distance.

AI: 5/10

This is the "best" thing in the game. If I could earn steam money for every time where an AI used their gun instead of melee a zombie. Sometimes they shoot when a zombie is not aggresive
hoursPlayed:
and making them and every zombie within 20 feet aggresive on you.

Total score: 7/10
It might seem like I'm hating on the game

It could have been so much better if they had fixed some of the things that have told you about in this review."

reviewText:
As a returning player of State of Decay with over 300 hours into the original, I felt I should share my feelings about Year One Survival Edition.  For the people who have played the original and want to know what was polished in this edition, here are the definitive improvements I have noticed so far (in addition to the more obvious changes that were made):

-  Ferals are nearly impossible to hit with a car.  They have some very responsive reflexes, leaping multiple times to dodge a moving vehicle and they will jump over your car if you kick it into reverse (so no cheesy brake kills in YOSE).

- Characters you've spent Influence on so they will tag along no longer run back to base when they get tired or injured, and they will continue to help out even if you take on a mission while out.  Previously, a lot of missions immediately forced them to run back to base.  I have run several missions and wiped out half a dozen infestations without my companion heading home.

Edit:  A friend of mine says his follower just ran off after accepting a Scavenger mission, so there may still be some missions that auto-kick the companion.  So sad.  Did some testing of my own and found that companions tend to leave when doing missions for survivor enclaves (scavenge, beseiged, etc.) but stick around during missions for your own community.  I have run several Ally in Trouble, Missing Survivor, Zed Hunt and 'needs a talking to' missions without my companion bailing.  Hope this elaboration helps.

- Juggernauts seem to have less health than before.  I continued my game on BD11 and managed to take one out with less than a clip of .22 bullets to the cranium.  To counter that however, there seem to be more of them out there (at least on higher BD levels) and I had to take out 3 of them on my first Ally in Trouble mission.

- Less Bloaters.  They were everywhere in the original on higher BD levels and they seem to have had a significant population reduction.  The number of Ferals and Jugs though seem to be higher than before.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

And for some of the annoyances that still exist:

- Zombies still clipping through walls.  I can see their heads but I just wasted a couple shots trying to hit them even though they are on my side of the fence.

- Still getting stuck on sidewalks.

- Fighting on hills can still be hazardous to your health.

- Still having some trouble getting companions to get in the damn car.  Just have to drive back and forth here and there.  There does seem to be a semi-fix added to YOSE where a companion who is running in place due to bad pathing will try an alternate route after a handful of seconds and get in the car.  This is only if they are already in motion (doing the running man on the corner of the car).  A companion who is standing still will continue to do so until you can trigger a new response by moving the car a bit.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

All in all.  I still enjoy this game a lot and I hope they address some of the bugs that have existed from SOD's inception.  But for what it is, I still gave a thumbs up because those glitches were annoying, but not nearly as bad as the completely broken companion AI.  If you were a fan of the game and can look past those glitches, YOSE is still a lot of fun to play.

I did have some issues with framerate, but I modified my settings to Maximum Graphics @ 1280x720 and it has become a hell of a lot smoother.  The draw distance isn't the best, but it's still a lot better than the original and the combat is much more fluid, the combat animations look much better and I love the improved variety of vehicles.

Note:  I am set up in the Fairgrounds on my BD11 group so I have not experienced the returning Snyder's Trucking Watchtower problem yet, but from what I have read, it still continues to plague that home site.

Edit:  I have decided to start over from BD1 on a new profile and will update this review as I progress through the breakdown levels again.

reviewText: This review is coming from a person who has not tried this game or the previous version at all. Well, tried most of the old version at least. I downloaded the crack a month ago and I realized that the game was rigged, or in other words, has an anti-piracy gig were zombies attack you in multiple hordes every single minute. Yeah, it has like Hell. I totally regret my decision. So, I wanted to buy it, so I waited and waited. Until this version came along. reviewText:
Summary- If you don't own the original SoD, read on. The game is solid.
- If you own the original SoD, this is just a minor update. Read below to find out what changed, and decide based on those and the current price tag.
- Shortly after release, there are bugs. New ones. I trust they will be fixed soon.

ReviewThere are many negative reviews from people who actually like this game, just expected something more from this new release of their old favorite. To them: please remember that Steam users might decide on purchasing the game based on your reviews. Your review should be about the game, not the maker's way doing business. This game is solid. Some say this is the best single-player zombie apocalypse survival game in the Steam market. I agree with them.

SoD:YOSE won't bring much for the owners of the original game though. These new features are:
- High-res menu items and icons
- Better lighting
- One new car type (SUV)
- Varied car paintings
- One new hero
- Many cool new weapons
- Some new combat moves
- Some new textures and 3D models (don't expect a lot!)
- You can re-case ammo in the original campaign and 'Breakdown' too, not just in 'Lifeline'
- You can find and use the military vehicle from 'Lifeline' in the original campaign and 'Breakdown' too
- Some new bugs, hopefully to be fixed soon (nothing game breaking to me)

About the game:

SoD is a third person open-world zombie apocalypse survival game, unfortunately only single-player, where you can manage a small survivor community, build and upgrade base structures, and research new items for your ongoing combat against an unlimited zombie horde. The game has perma-death, some RPG elements, a wide variety of weapons and you can use the environment to fight the hordes too.

The main campaign provides a mediocre story with a good atmosphere, and introduces you to the gameplay.

'Breakdown' is a sandbox version of the main story - you play on the same map, without the storyline. You start in a random location, find and join a community, and then take on its management. When all resources were used up, or you are just bored, there is a broken RV you can fix and use to take a few key members of your community to another area. It will be the same map, with all resources respawned randomly, where you will start in a random point (from your broken down RV) and have to build up everything again. As you repeat the previous steps, the horde gets stronger and stronger, and you will receive new, stronger survivors to reinforce your team. This is my favorite game mode.

'Lifeline' takes place on a new map, is more military-oriented and as such provides a different experience. It is a mixture of the previous two: there is some story, but you can decide to stay and continue saving people at an increased difficulty - with a global leaderboard.

Would I recommend this game?
- If you don't own the original, but like what you have read here, definitely.
- If you own the original and like it, maybe. You won't get much extra, so decide based on what I wrote earlier. Or wait for a sale.

reviewText:
For new players interested in SOD, yes I would reccomend this to you. For the vet players who own the original SOD and are debating about buying this one, think about if the new additions are worth the price tag to you. The game itself is basicly the same except with a few tweaks, visual improvements, new characters in breakdown and some of the breakdown challenges changed.

For new players:
State of Decay is a sandboxish zombie survival RPG. You switch between different survivors that have their own perks and personalities and try to gather supplies to help your group survive. There are lots of different weapons to use and there is a small RPGlike skill system. For example, if you spec a survivor in using blunt weapons then when that skill levels up enough you can pick 1 of 2 attacks for the survivor to learn. With firearms depending on what type the survivor specs in you can get better firerate, longer distance lockons, etc. The game also features perma-death so if your survivor dies, they are gone for good which adds a bit of tension when your trying to escape a horde or dealing with one of the freaks".

There are 3 modes in the game that you can play and they are:

Storymode:
The one you want to start with as it explains how you play the game. You follow the story of 3 survivors and without any spoilers
date:
basicly work on surviving and expanding your base as you help other survivors out and start learning about whats going on in the world.

Breakdown:
The main survival part of the game. You start out with a random survivor
recommended: pick an enclave group to join
hoursPlayed: then get to work surviving. The main goal is to find an RV and fix it up. Once you do that you pick which survivors you want to take with you to the next level and repeat. With each level resources become more scarce and zombies become more populated. There are also challenges that when you complete them
voteText:
unlock hero characters which have their own special perks and bonuses. Theres a small escort quest to bring them to your base and from then on if you restart breakdown you can then choose that hero to start with instead of a random survivor.

Lifeline:
This mode is unique because you take on the role of the army inside a city crawling with the infected. Your job is to simply scavenge supplies while extracting key VIP targets and any civilians you find. The key difference in this mode is that after a period of time you have to fight of a siege of the infected which gets steadily more difficult as you move on.

To sum it up
helpfulPercent: State of Decay ( or SOD ) is one of the best zombie games out there at least in my opinion. If you've never owned the original SOD and were interested in grabbing it
votesHelpful: then yes I would reccomend this to you 100%. As for vet players though
votesTotal: I know alot of them are angry about the support being dropped for the original and they do have a right to be. Its purely up to them if they want to buy this version for only a few new features.\n\nFor new players this is perfect for you. For the old vets
votesFunny: again just think if spending the money is worth for the extra features that they threw in."

reviewText:
Whilst a very obvious console port, if you can forgive the game for it's poorer aspects (melee combat doesn't feel completely fluid, zombies don't render well at distances, blurred textures, low dynamic shadow distance), you will have a blast. Big map, driveable vehicles, lots of items, customization, base/community building. Definitely worth the price in my opinion. Far from an 'AAA' title, but it has it's own charm.

Pros:
*Graphics are better than original release (albeit not significantly)
**Seems better optimized than the original release (from what I've tested I'm getting pretty-much a solid 60fps on Ultra)
***Very easy to mod (hordes of zombies, zombies do more damage, remove lit-up containers, remove zombie radar icons)
****Mods for the original game work on YOSE too
*****Map is a decent size
******Breakdown especially is very fun, lots of different characters, difficulty increases
*******An abundance of different items, weapons, levelling
********Different zombie types, adds to the excitement/fear without being too far-fetched

Cons:
*No anti-aliasing
**Assisted-aim with a controller can't be turned off
***Lootable containers (wardrobes etc) glow white, which kills immersion. Google: No More X-Ray Eyes to disable
****A hunger system would've been cool, but stamina forces you to eat which is an okay compromise
*****Can be buggy, can't climb on certain objects, etc
******I sometimes encounter a bug where if I die, and start a new character, a sound repeatedly replays which is incredibly irritating. Restart game to fix.

7/10. Not the best game I've ever played, but worth it for a cheap price. I'd happily pay ¬£20-$30 for it. Can definitely get a decent number of hours out of it. Just don't expect perfection.

reviewText:
There was a bit of debate and some doubt in my mind whether or not to get State of Decay: YOSE after reading a bunch of the reviews and seeing all the thumbs down. I have the older State of Decay and all the DLC for it already and I did enjoy that one greatly.I also had a few mods installed and I feel Yose adds what I already added in mods for the first State of Decay, which is a good thing. Now I don't have to add mods to get the experience I wanted with the first State of Decay. I like what they did with their zombie game, third person, having perma death, having to run a community of survivors the whole lot. I have gladly wasted many many hours. I certainly recommend the first one. If you are on the border about getting or not getting this. just go to youtube and watch a few videos and or reviews, find out with your own opinion about this game by seeing actual gameplay.

After playing this one for a bit I have no problem recommending this one as well. Sure i've seen a few weird zombie glitches, maybe a zombie gets stuck or you hit C to dodge and he grabs you anyways or you swing and somehow he manages to hit you brushing off your hit as wind in his hair, not really game breaking in my opinion, makes your odds less and in my opinion more fun as I welcome the challenge of staying alive. I also noticed the zombies like to spawn pretty fast even though I dispatch a ton and feel the area should be clear they keep on coming in waves appearing from thin air right in front of me. But I don't mind Killing zombies, it's fun and gets your stats up.

Most people say the game has frame drops, that it isn't optimized, the previous game ran smoother and it doesn't look better than the previous State of Decay, or it's not worth $20 for the exact" same game. I have not had any of these problems. I don't know what hardware people are using. I am on a modern mid level gaming computer ($600)

reviewText:
Short Answer: Fun Game, but is just an Improved State of Decay

If you bought the original State of Decay, Do Not Purchase This, at its full or current discounted price.

While this game is fun and entertaining still, even introducing a few much appreciated tweaks and upgrades, I could not in good faith tell someone to rebuy this game.

reviewText:
I'm going to preface this by saying that I did not own the game when it first came out. This is my first introduction to it and for the price it is phenomenal. I understand all the negative reviews and they are valid as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. But if you have never played this game, I would highly recommend you get this. I have become so emotionally attached to my characters that I have felt legitimate shock and sadness when they die. I've played 40 hours and am still on my first playthrough. I have been putting off main story missions and just messing around and looting. This game is awesome. It has its issues but overall I would definitely recommend this game to someone who hasn't played it and even remotely likes anything related to zombies, especially The Walking Dead. This game is the comic/show's close cousin and it fuses a bunch of great aspects of zombie culture and gaming into a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing great experience.

9/10


P.S. Obviously if you already have played State of Decay, DON'T BUY THIS OR YOU WILL BE MAD. The developer really should have released a disclaimer because their sheisty business practices have really ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed up this game's reviews. It is excellent if you are new to State of Decay. Otherwise it's a total ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing ripoff.

reviewText:
So I looked over the recent reviews and thought I'd pick this game up.  Seems like a majority of the people are clicking No" where it says  "Do you recommend this game?"  But in their reviews they recommend it for new players.  So.. which is it?

reviewText:
If you have played the original game, you may be wondering if the remastered version is worth buying. There are no significant improvements to the game, it's still the same game with a few nice changes. These changes do make the game more enjoyable but are probably not worth the full price. Improvements include:

-Enhanced graphics and draw distance, and new textures. The graphics aren't significantly better, but the difference is noticable.
-Improved effects, with dust, fog, and fire effects...
-More animations have been added. Zed's move differently, and they changed the unarmed combat.
-Cleaner looking interface.
-Some of the features in Lifeline have now been added to the main game and Breakdown.
-A new mission type, with new special weapons.
-Grenade launcher attachement and incendiary shotguns.
-More vehicles and some new skins.
-One new character is included (if you bought the original game).
-You can now play as Hawkes, Kilo, Vince and Sasquatch. (More dialogue was recorded for Breakdown).
-More music in game.
-Increased number of Zeds.

There are still some problems with the game. Zed's can pass through doors, and there are pathing problems (Surviors can get stuck when trying to enter vehicles).  Unfortunately there is still no support for 4k or 2k monitors. I have a 1440p monitor and I find it dissapointing (and I'm sure I'm not the only one) that I have to play the game at 1080p.

It may be better to wait for a discount, before considering to buy this game. Having glanced at some of the negative reviews, I agree that this game is not a major improvement, and there are still the same bugs. I suggest you buy this game if you haven't bought the original (or you bought the base game but not the DLC). For others, I suggest you wait for a discount. I still like this game and the improvements (particularly the new mission type), but graphically I expected it to be better.

reviewText:
Summarized:
Haven't played State of Decay before and have a love for zombie games? Buy it. Definitely worth it.

Have played it before, have money to spend and like minor changes and tons of minor extra stuff? Buy it. Cause they've added a lot of new things.

Have played it before while liking major overhauls or major changes? Then don't buy it. Nothing major has changed.[/b][/list]

Review:
I bought the original title without any of the dlc's 2 years ago and first played about 2 months ago.
Then I saw that a newer, more well done version of the game was coming out.  After seeing the discount and thinking about how addicted I was to State of Decay I decided to buy it.

If you're new to State of Decay or you've played the original State of Decay without the DLC's and/or you love zombie games like I do, you'll definitely like this game and it's going to be worth it if you have the money for it. It may take a little bit of getting used to but it's such an elaborate and amazing game. If you've played the original without the dlc's, it wouldn't be a bad deal to buy it since it includes the DLC's.

If you're not new to the game.. It may feel like not much has changed at all OR it may feel like a lot has changed. I think
the texture overhaul, extra weapons, extra survivors, extra mission, extra combat mechanics, better UI and extra cars are awesome and enjoyable. Most of the game has indeed not changed, but those extra things really make it feel like it did to me.

If you want to see a State of Decay that has undergone major changes, you shouldn't buy it. Cause it hasn't.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I'm reviewing this game as its own thing. IMO if you already own State of Decay and its associated DLC this is nothing more than a 1080p graphical update and is not worth the upgrade.

PC Specs (just in case):

AMD FX6300
NVidia GTX760
8GB of RAM
Played on a Microsoft Xbox 360 controller

What can I say about State of Decay other than it is the best zombie survival game in the market. It does a number of things really well:

1) Make every character feel unique

While you will always start with the 3 same characters, the community members you can acquire and how you build your characters can differ tremendously playthrough to playthrough. My first go at this game (in the 720p version) is completely different than my just finished 15 hours of playthough (on the Vanilla campaign). This game rewards smart play, some characters are more suited to melee and some for gunplay and building your characters around these strengths can help greatly or you can take the added risk of building evenly on every character. By the end of the campaign, I had three characters suited for gunplay, three for melee and two all-rounders and tasked each group to specific mission types. Everyone had a backstory and I tried to incorporate this into my decision making as I roleplayed them for what I thought each character would do in real-life. Each character also suffers permadeath and nothing is more heart-breaking than watching a character you build get destroyed by a silly move in a routine scavenging mission although after one or two deaths, you'll usually know when to pick your fights.

2) Simulate a zombie apocalypse.

Resources are scarce and while there are ways to end up not having to worry about resource A or B more often than not you'll run short on Resource C or D (there are five in total Food, Medicine, Ammo, Materials and Fuel). These resources are also consumed as the game is turned off meaning that you'll have to log in to check on the health of your community and to scavenge what you need. Which segues well into my next point. This game requires resource management. While you may be overflowing with food, not having enough medicine to stave off the flu or materials to maintain your defenses can and will spell certain doom. Adding to that is the fact that you can and will run out of resources, so it is a battle against time to stockpile resources and find a way out. Additionally, you will need to balance your time out as well. You will need to decide whether you want to clear the path around you or pursue story or community missions or scavenge for resources. You can roleplay as the hero of the community or the leader of your own isolated community depending on what you choose.

3) Combat is kinda awesome

There is nothing more awesome IMO that kneeing a zombie's skull open, or taking an oar and beating the crap out of multiple zombies. Melee combat in this game is great! You have your attack, dodge or (as I call it) space making moves that allow you to dictate melee fights with zombies. However, get overrun and surrounded and you will die. On the controller the Left Bumper (forgot the keyboard equivalent) allows you to add more power to your attacks, dodge further and finish grounded enemies all with the added cost of more stamina meaning that you can't just spam the attack button all the time.

Gunplay is tight as guns react as you'd expect forcing you to choose the range of engagements depending on the weapon you choose. Pistol's can't one tap enemies from as far as a rifle can, but rifles don't have the rate of fire as pistols do. Assault weapons are a happy medium but ammo for them is scarce and automatic firing will burn through ammo. There are plenty more weapons and I enjoyed using all of them, none of them felt particularly overpowered (though any weapon that can take a silencer should be top priority picks) and filled each niche appropriately.

4) Story

The story was in my opinion strongly average, there are some bits where you have to fill it in with your imagination but the game's narrative is relatively realistic with well-written dialogue. Needlessly to say, this is the most subjective part and I'll leave you to make this decision on your own.

In short, this is in my opinion the best zombie game out there and you should buy it if you are new to the series. Hordes of zombies can be either terrifying or exhilarating to fight against depending on how prepared you are to face them. In between all the fighting there's managing your community, resources and characters. Sprinkled on top of all this is a great melee combat system and great gunplay. The story is what you make of it honestly, I found it adequate to keep my playing and motivated to finish the game but it isn't going to win awards. Some technical stuff below.

Technical stuff

Graphics: Decent looking. I had everything on the Max preset (there's the Ultra preset after Max) and the game looked beautiful at times. What really detracted from the experience was the game slowdowns as you moved from area to area. It almost felt like the game kept reloading assets of the upcoming parts of the map leading to some noticeable stutter.

Sound: I liked how everything in this game sounded. Zombies whether aggressive or not sounded suitably dead and menacing. The guns sounded great, melee weapon effects were also pretty good. The ambiance came together very well for me.

reviewText:
I haven't played the original game, but I can understand why people who bought it, and then bought this version would feel cheated. I just found out about State of Decay, and so far the game is quite good. TL;DR The game doesn't really match the complexity of other open world survival games, and the PC-port is subpar.

The game is focuses more on being a sandbox. The story is very light, and dialogues brief. The voice-acting is good most of the time. Graphics are ok, but animations are quite cartoony, and there's never any really scary environments or events.

The world seems kind of small, most locations are just a stone's throw from the base, and distant locations take less than a minute to drive to. Scavenging is mostly about finding special lockers (about 2 or 3 per house) and looting them. There's no way to gather natural resources, or construct makeshift weapons on your own (ie. no crafting). Focus here lies instead on maintaining base happiness, upgrading facilities and managing resources. This is not entirely obvious how it works though - the interface is clunky, uninformative and its far too easy to misclick and start deconstructing rather than upgrading, thus wasting precious resources.

The interface and controls are painfully poorly ported. They do the job, but it's obvious that it was designed for a console controller, and very little effort was put into adapting it to a mouse and keyboard (even Skyrim did it better).

When it comes to zombie survival games, my main go-to game is Project Zomboid. In comparison, this game is easier, more cartoony; but also more immersive with the 3D environments, has some good NPC dialogue and adequate AI. For these reasons I think this game is entertaining enough to recommend, although some better controls would make it easier to recommend.

reviewText:
One of the best survival zombie game I've ever played.  Fun and addicting. Buy this only if you never played it like me.  Its worth it.  But if you own it, maybe give it a pass unless you REALLY love it like someone I know :)

I did not encountered any game breaking bugs.  Max resolution is 1080P, so if you looking to play anything higher, need some cfg tweaking like I did.  The sounds effects for this game is excellent.  From the slashing to the bashing of zombie, all add weight to them.  The DLC does add many more hours to the life of the game.  Are they fun? yes I had many hours of fun and I  never buy DLC.  This just comes with it.

overall excellent zombie game Must buy if you never own original.  Here comes the downvote haters.

reviewText:
I read these recommendations and lament; that in a world where hours are measured in dollars, I've owed thousands to this series compared with what I bought.

For two years I've played from Vanilla, to Breakdown, to Lifeline - sweeping the hordes on rusted-steel saddle, with a lasso burst from gunpowder, and a mania forged from clout. I've burned, I've savaged, I've salved, I've saved, I've cried, I've praised. It is the community by which we're raised. It is the loftiness of support, it is the understanding shoulder, the irrevokable lamplight in an otherwise sullied seam...

You can play your other zombie games, with an endless struggle of manacled, aging reflex against a toe-tapping slumber party of shamble crumblies with a penchant for frame-skipping in your general, meandering, stumbling, blathering direction, or you can drop that market wholesale and quaff the star motes of an untapped dream.

---

You take that entire genre, you break it down, and make it drown, then throw it a lifeline. Strip away all the non-essentials and see it for what it is. You take away its pretty vestments, its mini skirts and tube tops and stone-washed jeans. You strip away what society has made it, you strip away the old, superfluous tools of survival in whatever culture's theme, from the drip of alchohol to the baker's creme.

Crushing down all the trappings, enigmatically removing much, towards making whole.

Peeling off its Grecian idealism, its mustered motion of messosoprano Machina (Deus Ex), of lights at ends of tunnels, of softly spoken It'll be alright."

You take the pseudonym you once knew

votesFunny: empathetic solution's liquefaction - seeping heartward

salting now-ephemeral human wounds.

You stop.

Strike out!

Sweep the cliffs

column27: splashing hard around the ears.\n\nTil each wail's a windlass - descending downwards with a knell...cranial crevasses calmly creeping

knowing naught is all's been found.


This is your world

reviewText:
Notice:
Now understand before reading this two key facts: first and formost that I've only played 6 hours at the time of writing this. I will likely edit this review down the track if my opinion changes due to future gameplay. Secondly, that I have only invested $25 into State of Decay (paid $5 for the old one).

Introduction
Now onto the review itself, state of decay is a zombie survival game. You play a community trying to survive in what ever ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• walled building you can lay your hands on. The game itself is split into three gamemodes if you will: the main story, breakdown (loot the map and move onto a harder version of the map) and lifeline (I have played much of the last).

Graphics
Simply put the visuals feel clearer and more polished then the original game. There are a few dodgy textures here and there that feel like temp/hold overs but with some luck undead labs or modders can fix them. Also now supports 1080p which is nice.

Gameplay
Gameplay is much the same, you'll get the same dialog as before and you'll likely ignore it now like you did the last 100 times. A few new guns have been added (least I've been told) and there seems to be a pre-order character you can play now.

Overall
I'm not going to go nito the debat about if this one's better then the original or not. State of Decay: YOSE is a HD remake of one of the best zombie survivals (most likely the best one) that brings this two year old classic back from the dead (no pun intended =P).

What remains to be seen is what Undead labs will do with this new version of their game? Will they add more content (hopefully co-op, not holding my breath there though)? or just leave this game to rot in gaming hell (ok, that one was intended :D)?

reviewText:
I've put a little bit of time into the new version of the game and I am quite happy. I'm a previous owner of the game and all the DLC and thought it would be a great opportunity to see some of the graphics in a higher resolution with more detail. After some tweaking and some strangeness with the way the game changes resolution, I now have a great looking game running at 60+ FPS.

I had no problem spending $20 for the upgrade in graphics, the truck, survivor and weapons.  Great value for more high res fun.

It's a shame so many others are disappointed with this upgrade. I really thought it would get a better bunch of traction. Unfortunately, many don't share my belief that value is perceived differently by different people. This, this right here is great value. Buy it.

TL;DR: Buy this version of the game if you enjoyed the gameplay in the previous version or if you really enjoy slightly deeper zombie survival.

reviewText: Ok, yes. The game has bugs and glitches, and yes this should be fixed. BUT that's doesnt change my opinion that this is the best and most immersive survival game ever. If you are a true gamer and can overlook bugs and try to experience this game itself, then you will get a kick out of this game. I played it on xbox 360 and loved it, so i figured, hey, let's get the new version. The game is the same, but just feels better. You get so immersed in it you feel that it is a new story ever single time. You dont only do missions, you explore, build your base, clear zombies to make the area safer and so on... I personally think this version has nice graphics (BESIDES THE BUGS). Overall, if you are looking for a true zombie survival video game in which you will get fully immersed, then this is for you.

reviewText:
For the current prize if you want something a bit more casual to play for a time i recommend this game.
But with a fair warning that you also need some casual patience with it's performance. It's a fair price i can't complain about that.
here's why:

Still got a bunch of bugs in it.
Optimization leaves a bit to wish for. I have crashed twice, some serious pop in and stuttering issues when entering a new area or moving to fast in a car.
It's not that good of a port. Controls and UI not to mention camera can at times be frustrating but you quickly get used to it.

On average it's an okay zombie survival RPG it's not great by any means but it's heading in the right direction.
And it's sort of meant to be played a little bit each day instead of sinking hours upon hours into it. This helps with keeping the patience to.
Luckily if you want to spend some time on it there seems to be optimization mods around doing what the developers could not. And there is even some nice candy options to give it that nice PC master race standard looks.

reviewText:
To buy or not to buy, that is the question...If you own the game already.

People who already own the game and who are upset with the new verison, understand State of Decay was released for xbox live and the PC, you couldn't go into the store to buy it. State of Decay year one edition actually went into stoers because of it's success and basically it's just a way to get more attention to a great game.

I spent almost 240hours on the State of Decay, reaching level 13 on the Break down DLC and making it into the top 100 players. So this was an easy buy for me, just simply because I enjoyed the game so much, or too much. Now I'm on breakdown 28 or something and in the top 14 players.

Improvements?
The graphics are maybe 5% better
Fighting seems to have minor differences
More guns and you can craft your own bullets which improves gun play
SUV's and the army truck is added from Lifeline. The cars and trucks have new skins as well
New Characters
A bonus drop system called CLEO is in the game which is going to play into state of decay 2...You learn nothing about it.

If you really enjoy the game, get it for breakdown. Being able to make your own bullets now made guns a great weapon now and you feel like this bad a$$ pulling combos than going to slow-mo and killing zombies wtih your rifle...Rifles are the only guy really worth having in the game.

The game is a bit easier because of this, but also more fun. If you don't own the game buy it! If you want to go back to state of decay it's worth picking up, I bought it at full price because I'm crazy about the game, but I can see waiting for a big sale on it if you already own it.

I do wish they added a different type of Zombie, or opened up a few buildings, like the movie theater you can't get in, as well as just added some extra buildings.

reviewText:
In light of the bad reviews I've seen for this game, let me give a positive one.

Disclaimer: I've only had a chance to play breakdown thus far, so I have no comments on the main game quest or on lifeline, but I expect like everything else they will be like the original.

Summary:  If you enjoyed the original game, this version gives improved graphics and perhaps a tiny bit more gameplay stuff.  If you expected anything different than that, I don't know what to tell you.

The game plays like the original game, because *gasp* it is the original game.  All that was promised was improved graphics and a few little tidbits to make the game more fun.  It's basically a textures overhaul mod you'd expect to see for Skyrim, except its official.

I've heard complaints about the bugs, and all I can say is that they were neither better nor worse than the original game.  I'm guessing they were bugs that are driven by intricacies of the Cryengine version used be SOD, but that's just conjecture (it's all physics related and a few random crashes that honestly shouldn't happen, but I couldn't care less.)

As for the improved graphics, I noticed a huge improvement.  Everything was far less dingy, and undead labs seriously toned up the lighting.  While I can sort of get the realism of not being able to see at night, I'm glad they fixed it because for me the game was virtually unplayable during 'night'; if you want to be unable to see for 50% of the game I would then of course recommend the original.

They probably added new character traits, and definitely added new shirts and pants and hats.  This mixes up what sort of characters you will see and increases playability.  Similarly the vehicles were diversified and given new textures, which again makes for more replayability since there are more than 6 distinct cars in the valley.

I did in fact notice the higher res textures.  The original was grainy as heck.  The menu and maps have been cleaned up significantly, which is really good.  I'm so glad they kept the physical journal interface (the game menus look like pages in a notebook) ====== very cool UI.  Plus you can now tell which item you have selected!

In closing, the Year One edition is worth it if you liked the original game (or if you never played it, I suppose).  If you go in expecting a vastly different setting and feeling and a bug free game, then you'll be disappointed.

Good luck, it's a brutal game.

reviewText:
There's been some remarkable customer backlash over this being 'the same thing as before'. Well. State of Decay is a great game. This, right here, is a new edition of a great game. There aren't too many changes - this is, after all, a very slight upgrade which is primarily to make State of Decay available to X-Box One owners. On PC, the changes aren't too obvious, but there's a different engine running things in the background. There's a new knife-wielding mechanic for characters without weapons. There are new bits and bobs in various game modes, but again, they're marginal - new heroes, some bits of hardware from DLC being offered across all game mods, that kind of thing.

The 'consumer revolt' is entirely out of proportion with what this is, and with what this is advertised as. It's State of Decay running on an updated engine - same game, significantly different back-end... but it's the same game.

And it's a really, really good game. I bought it as an excuse to replay it, and I'm enjoying it. I think the developers did a pretty good job.

As somone who didn't buy the original SOD this game has ben great fun. There ae some problems with it for sure, such as lackluster environment textures and the controls aren't as responsive as I would like. But even with the problems the game as whole makes for an enjoyable addictive experience.

reviewText:
First impressions:
When I got the game, I expected the game to play like GTA and Project Zomboid had a baby. Instead it felt more like Dead Rising and Saints Row had a baby. The graphics are similar, and the car controls are about just as clunky when it came to sticky acceleration and steering delayed by milliseconds.

As far as I know, you can't loot the occasional weapon from a zombie (police/security zombie/randomly armed civilian). You have to search boxes within structures for loot instead. I don't own the original game because I got this one by mistake (I meant to get the first game), but it still plays great despite it's quirks. Not to mention killing the zombies feels great. I'm on the fence about recommending State of Decay: Year One to anybody else, but if others say the first game is better, I can't argue with it since I don't know.

I'll see about editing this reveiw with an update later once I've completed the game.

reviewText:
So first off, I'm not kibitzing about the YOSE - I have both the original and the remastered as it's kind of like the GoTY edition - those aren't given out to original purchasers either so I personally don't see the issue. I've played the hell out of this game and I love it even with its flaws.


The game looks nice. Maybe not 2015 Assassin's Creed, Witcher 3, Dragon Age Inquisition, etc. nice but it's not terrible. The effects are overall better and I enjoy the new look a lot. Unfortunately the textures break a lot and flatten out to look very low-res.

Cars handle better. Now that being said, they still handle really wonky at times. Car drives beautifully for a while and then you hit a small pebble or stick and car shoots into the air, slingshotting my character into a swan dive. Sometimes it does this for no reason at all. Textures on the cars break when my character is in them. Going from decent to low-res the second my character climbs in and sits down. There is no reason why a car sitting still should develop a case of the blurries. I do like the new vehicles UL added, they give the game a bit more variety and flavor.

Some pathing has improved. Some hasn't. I still get stuck on curbs and sandboxes and anything that is ankle height. I think my characters must all have weak ankles and thus have developed a fear of short objects.

Game difficulty seems cranked to 11. I started over instead of importing my save and opened up Breakdown lvl 1 (I prefer Breakdown to story TBH) and I was getting swarmed constantly. I lost one guy to a feral which is totally something that happens but a lot of survivors are getting mauled by packs of two and three zombies who glitch through doors and seem to hit like they migrated from a much higher difficulty. And OMG HORDES. Upon starting my game and moving into the Alamo, 6 hordes spawned. And each time there is a horde announcement, there are between 7 and 8 hordes. Half of these will almost instantly infest a house. It's kind of daffy.

Overall however, I feel this game is still wonderful. I do wish there were more features added - more home base sites, perhaps city access like when you choose to move on in Breakdown you could wind up in a Breakdown version of the city instead of the valley - more base-building freedom (Seriously. I'm looking at all this negative space in my bases wondering WTH I can't plop a garden planter here or more beds there..) and maybe a toggle on mission frequency. (STHU LILY. I'M BUSY!) But it's still a terrific game overall and I love it just as much as I did when I first played it.

reviewText:
I purchased the original State of Decay, and I have many hours on it.
I pre-purchased this game, and was amazed to see that I had 33% of the price deducted from owning the previous game! I also received an awesome in-game character, special to only previous supporters of State of Decay!
I have to start of with the STUNNING graphics. Somehow, these amazing graphics run on my computer (more like a toaster, but ya know what I mean) with very little lag.
The gameplay is FAR, and I mean REALLY FAR, smoother. There is no glitches that I've found (yet), which is awesome. The game actually looks epic, and the gameplay is too. While my game was downloading, I was reading the reviews, and was not feeling to good. I started to regret buying it, but now that I've played it I know how full of dog turd some people are. Whether it's your first time joining the State of Decay or you're rejoining it from the previous game, this is WELL worth the 29.99 USD (or the 19.99 USD for returning players).
I'm looking to enjoy hundreds of hours on this within a couple of months.
If you are looking at this game and want it, DO NOT hesitate. It's amazing. You WILL NOT regret. There is one thing about that though, this game is not for people who only have 5 minutes of game play time a day and who want to be an OP 'boss' in 2 minutes. You can't buy premium stuff, only the DLC for 2 extra game modes (Well worth the money).
This game WILL get boring over time. It did for me (with the original game, but it will with this one too), but I KEEP coming back for more. So the difference between this and your mom is...well...this one costs a few extra bucks! (It's just a joke, please take no offense).
I will probably be updating this comment at least once to let you know over time if this game has changed (for better OR worse), enjoy!
voteText: 11 of 36 people (31%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Okay, something none of the negative reviews seem to understand here. You have to realize what you're buying here. This is not a new game, never was advertised as one. If you spent five seconds researching what this new edition consists of, it is essentially a GOTY edition that you've seen on a hundred other games before. For those that already have the game, there will be little gained aside from minor visual and technical fixes alongside what could be considered a slight DLC addition, the new weapons/vehicles/etc. For those that don't have the game, it's a complete steal to pick it up now.

This game is as awesome as it always was. Considering the size of Undead Labs and the size of the crew that made this game, it is a very well done job. Considering the fact that I picked up the first game for $20 and this one for $20, I don't think I was ripped off in the slightest. This game is by far worth $40.

To all the people that hated all over this game, let me put it this way. Does it have paid mods? Does it have microtransactions? Was it made by EA? Shut up and enjoy an amazing game that is worth every cent charged for it.

In the previous version the lighting was terrible at times especially around dusk and sunrise, this new version makes me feel like someone turned on the lights.\n\nMyself I was happy to pay 20 bucks for the new version and I am excited to try out the rest of the new content.

reviewText:
This game is a very fun game and I like it quite a lot. It's a clever idea that still holds a lot of potential, the devs could still do very much with this game especially since they just 'remastered' it.

I played the original and I deffinately notice a difference with graphics and frame rate, mainly because I have a computer that wasn't exactly built for gaming. I can run the remastered game on ultra and 1080p just fine without frame drops, in comparison to me running medium to high graphics with violent lag and occasional crashes at times in the original.

However this does not constitute the developers charging (quite a bit) for a remake, several bugs are still present from the original but overall it's still very nice. It would have been nice if this remake was a free upgrade to whoever bought the original and It would also be nice if the devs were to add more content in the form of updates (In all seriousness, this is a huge oppurtunity to release some more content).

Overall, I'd say proceed with caution. This is still a very fun and enjoyable game. The game runs a lot smoother for me in comparison to the original and I noticed a few little changes. I'd say that if you didn't buy the original, buy this version. If you have the original, stick with that because you might be disapointed.

reviewText:
While I do agree that this is how the PC release should have been to begin with, I'm not going give a negative review based on that fact as it would be petty.

Because the truth is, if you've never played this game or you own the original, I'd recommend it nonetheless.  Its the only real single-player driven zombie survival experience you're really going to find that delivers on the survival front AND gives you some interaction with the world itself in the form of other NPC survivors.

While I've played 7 Days to Die (and I do recommend that game) and Project Zomboid (another great game but it still has a long way to go) and a few others, I found myself playing this one out of the batch the most.  Mostly because the worlds in those games are...well, empty currently, though I intend to revisit them when NPCs survivors are added.

While the world itself is solid and interactions with it are limited (you can board up houses, establish outposts, rescue other survivors but you can't say, build an entirely new building from the ground up) it delivered what I had hoped and that was a zombie experience with some drive beyond, I'm going to go on and on and on..." because while survival is fun
date: it is not inherently interesting if that is all you're doing (in a virtual space
hoursPlayed: the game gets downright difficult as time progresses; there are some serious heavy weight zombies that you don't even want to run into while you're driving a vehicle.  Your insurance won't cover it

reviewText:
This game is what they say it is.... A remastered game with far better graphics. This is an independant studio which developed a unique product to fill a niche in the market. When they achieived great success because of the design of the product, they made money.

Still independent, they elected to redo their game with better graphics. They still aren't a massive company with huge budgets, but they do care enough about their creation to want to do it right.

This game is the the same unique design which the first released, but with a far better framework than what they had the capabilities of releasing before because of money.

Support indy developers who buck huge companies and purchase games which are focused on enjoyment, not making piles of money.

FYI, the framework is far better, so now they can release additional dlc to add lots of new content (something they very successfully did with the original.....

I can't wait.

reviewText: State of Decay Year One Survival Edition is the most enjoyable single player end of the world Zombie game available. Period. Part simulation and all action the game looks good and the Gore is very abundant. The controls are quick and responsive and the fear of character permadeath keeps you on your toes. There is a bit of clipping and a few isolated graphical bugs that some people cry and complain about but these do not stop or distract from the immersion or enjoyment of the game in any way. I owned it first on my Xbox360 and then purchased it for my computer. Don't listen to the fussy detractors. They are nit-picking and looking for things to criticize in this good quality budget game. If you think you'll enjoy a captivating open world head popping Zombie smashing simulation then State of Decay might be your game.

reviewText: I've seen a lot of blasting in the negative spectrum for this game. I really just couldn't disagree more. I played a LOT of the original version of this, and there is clearly a great improvement on the graphics qualities. Texturing of wood is noticeably better, and details and shadowing of characters and zombies are improved as well. The trees look fantastic (not that they were bad before.)      It's easy to hate on a game, but you won't see me doing it with this one. There are new animations, new sound effects, vehicles... the menus have been revamped (i.e. inventory)        I love it. I've experienced no glitches yet either. And if they arise, Undead Labs has always been good about fixing problems. Love it. Thanks guys!

reviewText:
I find all these negative reviews a bit unfair and misleading for the game and for new players as almost everyone base their negative review on faultered/not reached hopes and hypes. If we are to review ONLY the new parts of the game, then it's one thing. But if we are to review this as a whole game, for new and unaware players, then all this criticism are misplaced. Therefore these negative reviews is a shot to the head on a really great game.

If you are new to this game and you like the Zombie/survival genre, then this is (in my opinion) one of (if not THE) the best game there is to date. You get to survive/live in a pretty realistic interpretation of a post-apocalyptic zombie-virus outbreak. Vehicles, basebuilding, team-management, permadeath and scavaging. Done in a really genial way. Even with some RPG elements!

What needs to be fixed is the framrate/optimization issue. When travelling by car the game does not run very well, a problem I never had with the original. And a very personal opinion of mine, as I understand the hordes (maybe zombie overall) spawnrate has been increased. One of the (by me) strongest sides of SoD compared to other games in the same genre is that there is peaks of intensity. Your not overun 24/7, the world can seem silent and peaceful one minute and then hell breaks loose the next. I really hope it will stay that way.

So. If your into the Zombie/survival genre, for the survival ideas, this is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing awesome game and worth every penny! Can't wait for the sequel!

reviewText:
YOSE is State of Decay's GOTY.  And it is a damn good one.

PROs:
+Butter-smooth framerate and animations
+Crisp graphics.  Textures are far less muddier than the original.  The world is more vibrant
+UI looks cleaner
+New unarmed knife combat is pretty slick
+The mods I had installed have worked right away (though icons need to be edited)
+Literally picked up in my Breakdown game exactly where I left off in the original

CONs:
-Zombies still pop in.  Not a con for me, but worth noting for others
-Still can't use the Court House as a Home!  In fact, I don't think any new potential homes were added
-Still can't put a rucsac in the bed of a truck without a mod

TL:DERRRRRR- A great game made better.  If you're not burnt out on SoD, there is no reason not to own this iteration of it.  It does not feel like a completely different game, but it does feel like the original greatly enhanced, which was what this iteration was aiming for.  For an XBLA title, this game is really freakin' sweet.

reviewText:
A good game and a better PC port than the original State of Decay.  Still needs a better graphics menu as at the moment there's really no way to tweak things like AA etc.  Would be nice to have these options.

Performance isn't bad consideing it uses the CryEngine, but it does stutter a little bit here and there.

However I haven't yet played enough of this game to give it a full on review.

A few problems

- There was a mission where the army had two surviors on the floor but said survivors were invisible and it looked like the soliders were talking to themselves.
- Graphics menu isn't that great. We can't adjust anything such as AA.
- Frame rate can vary wildly.  Although on my system this isn't game breaking its something to consider.
- Car handling is a bit weird.  They seem to turn a bit slow.


A few good things
- Gameplay seems a lot better compared to the last State of Decay.  Doesn't feel as clunky.
- Graphics have seen a decent overhual.  Looks a lot better than the previous State of Decay.

My recommendations to the developers
- Give us more options to tweak. The slider doesn't really tell us anything. This may even help the performance of the game for a lot of people.

reviewText:
Really loved the game; still do, but I'm disappointed the graphics aren't as good as I hoped. If you haven't played the original, definitely get this one, but veterans may be slightly underwhelmed with a high powered system. I was hoping that it would display at 4K, but it is still limited to 1080 resolution on PC. (That is, cannot select a res above 1080, at all... -fullscreen launch option used to work, but now does not).

Perhaps the GTA V PC remaster has ruined it for me. I would also have liked some AA settings, or any graphics configuration settings to tinker with. The only really noticable upgrade is the UI/Journal screen...gr8!

Considering this remaster doesn't add much content and was marketed as a purely graphics upgrade (which is why I bought it) I am, actually, REALLY disappointed. I still recommend it though, but only if you haven't played it before.

reviewText:
State of Decay: YOSE - What's new in this version?!
State of Decay: YOSE is the remake for State of Decay Undead Labs worked on.

What a great game,

YOSE Day One Edition adds so much to the game, even if you played State of Decay and all the DLCs like I did there's still so much stuff to do, I totally recommend getting it!

Undead Labs added so much stuff, if it's in new challenges and Achievements or in features like new DVR, knives, vehicles, weapon add-ons, new music, unlockable characters and more!

There's even a 33% discount for users who own State of Decay if you buy until June 30, 2015 - just purchase from the account that own the original game!

There's new knife animation, YES the default melee is a combat knife! good for 1v1 but not for more than 2 zombies at once! (so it's not OP and there's still reason to carry a melee weapon!)

And the graphics looks AMAZING!, the developers did great job with bringing State of Decay to the 1080p. plus there's an improved lighting, textures, and shadows which makes the game beautiful more than ever before.

Also the UI looks so clean and good, really love it! :D

To sum up, you're going to enjoy the game so much, there's a lot of new stuff to do and much to discover! :)




Reviewed on http://scop3scout.webege.com/State_of_Decay_YOSE

reviewText:
First of all: if you have not played State of Decay before then this is worth it.
It's a great storydriven sandbox zombiegame. The combat is a bit bad, but hey you win some you lose some.
You can spend hours with searching for resourses and doing quests. It is an unpolished diamond and you should not miss it.

If you have the game it's a maybe....

See I played the original without the DLC and loved it, and for me this was worth it just for the DLC.
If you have the original game and the DLC this is not worth it at all. It's still good and the graphics is sligthly better.
But that is not worth you rebying essentially the same game for that. It's still good, but as unpolised as it ever was.
The bugs are still there and  so all the other problems.

Yet it is still an entertaining experience and if you do not already own it you should pick it up.
Should you already own the base game, wait for a sale and buy it then.

reviewText:
Update: My issues have been addressed, changing to thumbs up.

For $19.99 I got a handful of minor new features, worse (IMO) graphics with more glitches, and a host of new bugs. All of the bugs I was hoping would be fixed are not.

It honestly feels like I just installed a handful of mods that (as usual with mods in my experience) destabilize the game.

Things I'd hoped for: Updated textures, higher resolutions without -fullscreen, a couple more home sites, and many of the commonly complained about bugs fixed. I got none of that.

I would like to recommend this game to new players but I can't.  The bugs that plagued the original version are still not fixed and yet they discontinued support for that game.  It is unlikely they will fix most of the bugs in this version too.

I will say this.
I played this a few times but I had FPS drop but it wasn't a big deal 50-60.
The only weird bug I found was defending a base from survivors then Juggernaut spawn inside a house.
This game has so many baby sit, it get's  annoying to keep helping other survivors when they are across the street -__- TF. I just want to explore and try to get everything from the map but I keep having issue with the Survivor that they are in trouble.

My recommend:

reviewText: I been playing State of Decay (original version) for close to two years. The Breakdown DLC is what keeps me coming back to this game. With Year One version:  new female character and The Cleo missions are an added plus, but some buggy issues with the original version are still present. reviewText:
YOSE is State of Decay plus DLC's and added bonus items for owners of the older version. Better Graphics, New Mission, Better NPC AI.

YOSE feels more dangerous more zombies,More Specials really keep you on your toes.

This game has a bad Rep is it worth 20-30 dollar asking price I say Yes.

Only you can decide if it is worth it to you....  it is to me....

UPDATE

It's been a year since the above review and the game has had only 1 hotfix type patch and 1 normal patch after the last patch company blamed all remaining bugs on unity engine and abadoned all future support of the game in favor of a still unnamed Class 4" MMO project after trying and failing (to the extent of not even making it out of Early Access) at a Mobile and F2P MMO.

Would I still recommend it? NO

Price is way to high wait for sale"

reviewText:
I should probably point out that the original state of decay was the first ever open world zombie apocalypse game that I played. Long before DayZ, H1z1, etc. I put 46 hours into the original version of this game. I bought this version hoping for more, but basically just got the exact same game with updated graphics and sound and some general improvements to gameplay. If you've never played the original state of decay, I would suggest you play this... but I think the price of $30 is too much. Buy this game while it is on sale.

PROS:
-You are in an open, zombie infested world and can essentially go wherever you want and do basically whatever you want as long as you live. You have to rest though and the bigger your group is, the better off you are, as long as you keep supplies stocked. There is a story and you have to follow it if you want to beat the game, but technically you can just survive and explore as often as you prefer.
-You can grow a garden, build a medical center and can craft sniper towers in your base. There is some customization of bases in this game and it is interesting.
-You must maintain supplies such as food and medical. You can raid houses, factories, schools and collect weapons and loot.
-You can recruit other AI players that you meet, or you can deny them. You can let them into your group and if they start acting crazy you can send them packing or help them. You can control several different characters in the game and can decide who you want to play as, as you go.
-You can establish a base where you can build a small community of survivors.
-There are vehicles throughout the world you can take and drive. You can use the trunk to stash extra supplies to transport to your base. Driving around in this game feels a lot like the open AI world of Grand Theft Auto
-Different types of zombies provide various levels of challenge to kill. Sometimes hoardes come upon you while you are raiding a house for loot and you end up having to barricade yourself inside Night of the Living Dead" style.
-The story
date:
acting and soundtrack are all excellent. They keep you interested and engaged in the game.

CONS:
-There is no online mode. You cannot play co-op or with anyone online. This is a single player game only. This is a massive strike for some people
recommended: but understand that this is still a great game without online.\n-You have to play this game in 3rd person. There is no option for 1st person.\n-There is no way to customize your characters. You have to play as the survivors on the game. Lack of customization. You can techincally mod the game unofficially
hoursPlayed: but it can cause crash problems.\n-The map lacks very large structures to loot inside of
voteText: such as a large hospital or large schoolhouse. You spend most of your time looting houses and small shacks or warehouses.\n-There are no real destructable environments. Sure houses burn down and cars explode... but that's about it. You can't pull a fire axe out and chop a hole into a wooden house."
